outline_text: Banning gas-powered leaf blowers reduces harmful noise and pollution, improving urban health. Introduce issue: gas-powered leaf blowers cause noise and pollution problems in cities Noise pollution harms residents' well-being and mental health Gas engines emit pollutants contributing to urban air quality decline Alternatives like electric blowers are quieter and eco-friendlier Personal choice risks ongoing environmental and health damage Conclusion: banning gas-powered blowers improves city health and quality of life
human_draft_text: All cities should ban gasoline-powered leaf blowers to reduce both excess noise and air pollution. Gasoline-powered leaf blowers are a major contributor to urban air pollution because almost all run on compact two-stroke engines. While power-dense, two stroke engines produce significant air pollution because lubricant oil is mixed with the fuel in the engine's combustion chamber. The high levels of pollutants emitted by the exhaust from leaf blowers, such as nitrous oxide, contribute to urban air pollution and damage the health of the most vulnerable city residents.   Furthermore, gasoline-powered leaf blowers are a major contributor to urban noise pollution. Gasoline-powered leaf blowers can emit sound levels of up to 120 decibels at full power, which can cause permanent hearing damage with prolonged exposure. The negative effects on urban residents are palpable, especially when viable alternatives exist.  Electric leaf blowers have advanced significantly in the past decade. With powerful lithium ion battery technology, electric leaf blowers offer comparable or superior performance to gasoline-powered leaf blowers without the emissions. There are no real advantages remaining to gasoline-powered leaf blowers—they are more polluting, less reliable, emit significant noise pollution, and degrade urban air quality. All of these negative externalities are issues which simply cannot be addressed by personal choice alone.  While some may argue that individual residents should be able to choose between electric and gasoline power, that argument ignores the significant drawbacks of continuing to allow highly-polluting gasoline-powered leaf blowers to remain on the market. To transition leaf blowers to clean, four-stroke engines equipped with catalytic converters would make such leaf blowers almost prohibitively expensive for the average consumer. It is far simpler to simply ban gasoline-powered leaf blowers to ensure that the residential market is serviced by clean, efficient, and emissions-free electric leaf blowers. In doing so, cities have a significant opportunity to improve air quality and the health of their residents without a significant financial impact.
final_text: All cities should ban gasoline-powered leaf blowers to reduce both the excess noise and the air pollution emitted by their widespread use.   First, Gasoline-powered leaf blowers are a major contributor to urban air pollution because they almost all run on compact two-stroke engines. While power-dense, two stroke engines produce significant air pollution because lubricant oil is mixed with the fuel in the engine's combustion chamber. In addition, to keep costs low, most are not equipped with emissions equipment such as a catalytic converter. The high levels of pollutants emitted by the exhaust from leaf blowers, such as nitrous oxide, contribute to urban air pollution and damages the health of the most vulnerable city residents.   Second, gasoline-powered leaf blowers are a major contributor to urban noise pollution. Gasoline-powered leaf blowers can emit sound levels of up to 120 decibels at full power, a level of sound which can cause permanent hearing damage with prolonged exposure. The negative effects on urban residents are palpable, as anyone who has been subjected to a neighbor blowing leaves for an extended period of time can attest.  Third, electric leaf blowers have advanced significantly in the past decade. With powerful lithium ion battery technology, electric leaf blowers offer comparable or superior performance to gasoline-powered leaf blowers with zero tailpipe emissions. There are no real advantages remaining to gasoline-powered leaf blowers—they are more polluting, less reliable, emit significant noise pollution, and degrade urban air quality without any accompanying edge in performance.  All of these negative externalities are issues which simply cannot be addressed by personal choice alone. While some may argue that individual residents should be able to choose between electric and gasoline power, that argument ignores the significant drawbacks of continuing to allow highly-polluting gasoline-powered leaf blowers to remain on the market. To transition leaf blowers to clean, four-stroke engines equipped with catalytic converters would make such leaf blowers almost prohibitively expensive for the average consumer. It is far simpler to simply ban gasoline-powered leaf blowers to ensure that the residential market is serviced by clean, efficient, and emissions-free electric leaf blowers. In doing so, cities have a significant opportunity to improve air quality and the health of their residents without a significant financial impact.

By acting quickly, they can rescue many Americans from the current economic handicap that they face by having student loans. This can be accomplished quickly by the federal government. They will be able to immediately feel this relief. It is incumbent on the federal government to make this a reality for all Americans and not just some Americans. Student-loan forgiveness is the right solution for the American economy. It will make the American economy stronger and benefit all Americans.

final_text: The federal government should definitely broaden student loan forgiveness programs. To be able to afford college, many people will often take out sizable loans with high interest rates at an age where they may not know the full consequences of their actions, and they are not fully informed about loan repayments. Research by the National Endowment for Financial Education indicates a significant number of students underestimate loan repayment obligations, leading to long-term financial strain. Federal student loans generally have lower fixed interest rates compared to private loans, which often carry higher rates. Expanding forgiveness programs could prioritize those with high-rate private loans or significant loan burdens relative to income. With the addition of interest, the amount people have to pay back may be much larger. Because of this, they feel like they cannot move on with life and afford things like property or children.   In addition, helping graduates with student loans will benefit the government. Today, many people do not approve of how the government manages policies, nor do they feel that representatives are acting in the interests of the people who voted for them. Expanding student loan forgiveness programs can definitely put the government in a better light.  For example, polls following recent loan forgiveness announcements showed increased approval ratings for certain lawmakers and heightened public trust in government actions relating to economic relief.  While the government can find other ways to address education debt, and they should, it would be much easier to make changes to a system that is already in place, rather than creating an entirely new system, that representatives will have to agree on. The process of creating something completely new will just prolong the time graduates are paying off their student loans, History shows that comprehensive loan reforms often face lengthy legislative debates and delays, whereas expanding existing programs can be implemented more quickly through administrative actions. For example, the Department of Education can expand forgiveness through regulatory changes or executive action, which circumvents prolonged legislative gridlock seen in past reform attempts. and with how divided the government is today, there is also no guarantee that representatives would agree on a new system to address education debt, whether reallocating funds or introducing policies that completely forgive student debt. The cost of education in the United States is something that needs to be addressed, especially with the rising costs of attendance and stagnant wages.

Rather than banning all phones en masse, public schools could give students limited access to smartphones to enhance learning, enhance safety and teach responsible digital behavior.   When used properly, smartphones can promote classroom engagement and academic growth. Students who have access to educational apps, online research and interactive quizzes are more able to explore basic learning ideas dynamically. Students who access educational apps, online research, and interactive quizzes can engage more deeply with basic learning concepts, making lessons more interactive and personalized. For example, schools integrating apps like Khan Academy have observed increased student participation and test scores, highlighting how smartphones can enrich learning. They promote deeper dives when in-class resources or studies are limited or reach their end.   In emergency situations, smartphones would serve a critical purpose. Imagine a sudden health or safety threat. For example, in the case of a sudden health emergency like an asthma attack, students can immediately call for help using their smartphones. Having a smartphone offers both parents and students a peace of mind. It's a simple measure that can streamline communication when it matters most. For instance, during recent school emergencies, students quickly alerted authorities or parents using smartphones, enabling faster responses and improved outcomes.   On the topic of digital responsibility, with structured guideline supervised use, schools can help students develop healthy habits with boundaries. Schools can implement digital citizenship curricula like Common Sense Education, which has proven effective in improving students' online behavior and decision-making skills. Studies show that students participating in digital citizenship programs demonstrate reduced cyberbullying incidents and improved online decision-making skills. Better informed choices would lead to better discipline and help prepare for the complete digital world.   Smart phones also act as tools of inclusion. For students without access to computers or internet at home, phones may be their only gateway to online learning. If a student is having trouble with translations, needs audio readers or other types of assist, a smartphone can help bridge the gap by increasing productivity for those who need it.   In conclusion, a balanced and thoughtful approach to smartphones will allow schools to focus on the benefits of use while minimizing risks. When used wisely and sparse, phones can empower students, increase safety and help teach tech awareness to students. Rather than seeing smartphones as a threat, we should exercise their advantages.

final_text: Student loan debt has become a crisis of epic proportions, garnering front page headlines and myriad discussions. As the price of an American college education has ballooned over the past decades, gone are the days of paying for a semester of undergrad with a summer job slinging burgers. Instead, millions of Americans and their families are saddled with tens of thousands of dollars of student loan debt, which they spend the most important years of their life struggling to pay off. Republican politicians are currently bemoaning the falling birthrate, but many young adults feel that their economic situations are too precarious to have children. Student-loan forgiveness is logical, compassionate, and smart, and the future of America depends on it.

human_draft_text: Many things have changed in our modern world since the events of the Covid Pandemic - While most things have settled down and gotten back to where they once were, one can't deny that the rise in America's remote workforce might be one of the largest lingering effects of a  horrifying chapter in US History. Many have grown quite accustomed to the idea of working from home - many prefer it, and some can't stand it. We have seen a major growth in many empolyees requesting that their remote allowances be extended somewhat, if not permanently. They cite an improvement in quality of life, and more balanced work/life symbiosis. They seem happier in their jobs than they have ever been previously, and seem to thrive working from home.   Unfortunately, we are seeing so many companies and big businesses that once embraced the remote adaptation slowly beginning to pull back on the leash. Some companies have even opted to reel their employees back permanently, completely removing their remote options, while other's prefer to allow their workforce some of the freedom still, just in smaller quantities, by requiring workers to return to the office for a minimum number of hours each week.  So the big question... Should large companies require workers to meet an office/home balance,? I don't see why... The workers are happier than ever working remotely. Which means they are more productive employees. Why ruin such a great thing for no good reason? It saves money on both ends... Less office supplies and less spent on office utilities, while employees save on gas and transportation, uniform costs, and keep a healthy work/life balance. To me, it's not even a question of should? But more of an unwavering WHY?  We've made so much progress in employee happiness since the Pandemic. Lets not destroy it!
final_text: Many things have changed in our modern world since the events of the Covid Pandemic - While most things have settled down and gotten back to where they once were, one can't deny that the rise in America's remote workforce might be one of the largest lingering effects of a  horrifying chapter in US History. Many have grown quite accustomed to the idea of working from home - many prefer it, and some can't stand it. We have seen a major growth in many employees requesting that their remote allowances be extended somewhat, if not permanently. They cite an improvement in quality of life, and more balanced work/life balance. For example, employees often save hours weekly by avoiding commutes and report greater flexibility in managing personal and family responsibilities. They seem happier in their jobs than they have ever been previously, and seem to thrive working from home.   Unfortunately, we are seeing so many companies and big businesses that once embraced the remote adaptation slowly beginning to limit remote work options. Some companies have even opted to reel their employees back permanently, completely removing their remote options, while others prefer to allow their workforce some of the freedom still, just in smaller quantities, by requiring workers to return to the office for a minimum number of hours each week.  So the big question... Should large companies require workers to meet an office/home balance? I don't see why... The workers are happier than ever working remotely. Which means they are more productive employees. Studies such as those by Stanford University found a 13% increase in productivity for remote workers, though this can vary depending on job type and individual preference. Why ruin such a great thing for no good reason? It saves money on both ends... Less office supplies and less spent on office utilities, while employees save on gas and transportation, uniform costs, and keep a healthy work/life balance. To me, it's not even a question of should; it's an unwavering why  While some argue in-person presence fosters better collaboration and company culture, flexible hybrid models can balance these benefits with employee satisfaction. We've made so much progress in employee happiness since the Pandemic. Lets not destroy it!

outline_text: The humble rabbit - example of devestation in Australia when humans reintroduced it. Dangers of thinking we know how nature will progress, or how animals adapt.   We can't be sure how it interferes with other wildlife.   Potential pathogens? - Probably not.   Nature adhors a void. Where we see devestation, nature sees a canvas to paint. Destroyed ecosystems can become vibrant if we back off.   Moral argument - is there any limit to what we should reintroduce? Are we responsible for every creature that ever existed? What about the other animals that would die to make ecological space for newly introduced animals.   No animal lives in isolation, its part of a greater whole.
human_draft_text: Behold the humble rabbit. Cute. Floppy-eared. Good for hunting? Thomas Austin thought so, what could possibly be the harm in bringing a few with him to his new home to hunt in his idle time. A century later, Australia is still living with the consequences of that decision. Without any natural predators, the two dozen rabbits introduced by Mr Austin bred out of control, utterly devastating the local ecosystem as they ate through everything vaguely edible.  There are two lessons to learn from Mr Austin, other than that bunnies are secretly terrifying. First is that humans have a terrible track record in trying to control ecosystems, and once unleashed, it can be far harder to fix than it was to originally execute. Second, no animal exists in isolation, it exists as part of an ecosystem. Plucking species out or inserting new species in is like thinking you can replace a jenga piece with a gooey slab of jello and that because they're both roughly the same shape, they'll serve the same purpose.   So too with reintroducing the wooly mammoth. This wasn't an animal that existed in isolation, it existed in concert with its ecosystem which kept both it and its environment in balance. While it's sad the mammoth is now gone, the ecosystem has already adapted to its loss, and you can't just slot one piece back in and think everything is fine than that jello piece is going to be a reliable building block.  Further, nature is an ever-changing force. The world is not what it once was, and the future will not be how it is now. Trying to force the future to mirror the past is anathema to the fundamental nature of... nature. The era of the wooly mammoth is gone, and that's made room for other species.

human_draft_text: The question of whether employees should be required to work from the office or if they may work remotely from home has become a hot topic of discussion in recent years, particularly in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic. As more and more companies begin to roll out return to office mandates, the question becomes even more relevant: Should large employers require workers to return to the office several days a week, or allow fully remote schedules by default? While there are benefits to working in the office, such as building a sense of community amongst employees, there are also just as many benefits to working remotely, such as saving time and money on commuting. Thus, a third option is introduced: the hybrid work schedule.  A hybrid work schedule is a money-saving move, both for the employer and the employee. Employees save money in a variety of ways, including spending less money on childcare, gas, parking, and paying for lunch at work. At the same time, the employer sees a financial benefit - fewer days in the office results in a lower utility bill and spending less in rent for your office space. Hence, the financial benefits can be reaped by both parties.  In addition, hybrid work allows for the perfect amount of flexibility in scheduling and supports work-life balance for employees. Employees who are not spending time commuting are afforded extra time to spend on hobbies, engaging in self-care, or with their families and friends. Employees who have time to spend at home are less likely to experience burnout and more likely to be productive employees. This flexible schedule also allows a company culture to be built, creating a sense of community amongst employees. Overall, the flexible schedule of hybrid work provides benefits to the employees that, in turn, cause increased productivity at work and better outcomes for the employer.  Finally, a hybrid work schedule allows companies to attract and retain top talent. It also promotes enhancing productivity of workers and boosts satisfaction/morale amongst employees.  In conclusion, a hybrid work schedule is the most idyllic solution to the age-old question of working in-office or remotely. Hybrid schedules provide an effective balance benefiting both employers and employees, making it the ideal choice for work schedules.

human_draft_text: I have been startled awake more times than I can count by the horrible, grating noise of a leaf blower being used in a yard. By neighbors, by landscapers in an apartment community, by city workers - it really doesn't matter, at this point my response to that noise is visceral. "How are these wretched machines even allowed?" I have muttered to myself multiple times. The bottom line is that they shouldn't be. Cities and towns are well within their rights to outlaw the use of leaf blowers within their city limits, and I am strongly in favor of the idea that they do just that.  There is precedent for this in many cities and towns already. The entirety of Southern California is governed by a board who instituted a leaf blower turn-in/disposal program. Companies and individuals received incentives to hand their pieces of equipment over. This was met with enormous success. Absent a small yet pervasive cause of noise and pollution, the cities in the area were that much cleaner. Incentives for landscaping companies and homeowners who take part in such a program could go a long way in encouraging people to clear these awful things out of their garages or sheds. Discounts on energy bills, water, anything that a city could reasonably offer people would encourage word of mouth to spread just as quickly, as would social media posts about such a program.  On the other hand, penalties could be imposed on those who do not cease the usage of leaf blowers. No landscaping company is going to want bad press or lack of support from an entire city. Homeowners aren't going to enjoy penalties or fines either. In the spirit of moderation, a rule could be enacted that leaf blowers could only be used if it is out of earshot of any other property, and can only be used for a set amount of time in a day. Nearly every other company that creates air emissions or noise complaints has to follow identical guidelines such as that in order to carry on with business.   I believe nothing sparks creativity more than the absence of something else. For instance, living in an area where the county has "accidentally" drilled through our water line shutting off our water supply three times inside of six months, I have had to get very creative during the entire days without running water in my house.

ai_draft_text: In today's schools, smartphones have become almost as common as textbooks. Most students bring their phones to class, but these devices often serve as more of a distraction than a help during the school day. The debate over whether public schools should ban smartphones or allow limited use is ongoing, reflecting the challenge of balancing technology's benefits with its drawbacks.  On the positive side, smartphones can be valuable tools for learning. They grant students quick access to educational resources, digital textbooks, and research materials, which can enhance classroom activities and assignments. Furthermore, having a phone during emergencies is reassuring for both students and parents. In urgent situations, students can immediately call for help or contact family members, ensuring safety and timely communication.  However, the disadvantages of allowing unrestricted smartphone use are significant. Phones often divert students' attention from lessons, leading to decreased focus and poorer academic performance. Additionally, smartphones can facilitate cheating during tests or assignments by providing access to unauthorized information. Beyond academics, they can also be misused for bullying or other social misconduct, exacerbating issues like cyberbullying within the school environment.  Given these considerations, I believe that smartphones should be permitted on campus but must be turned off and stored away during instructional time. This policy strikes a balance by allowing phones for emergencies or specific educational activities as exceptions while minimizing distractions. By keeping phones out of sight most of the time, schools can foster a more focused learning atmosphere without completely banning technology. Students can still benefit from their smartphones’ educational and safety functions without letting them interfere with their studies.  In conclusion, smartphones have a valuable role in modern education but must be used in moderation. A policy that restricts phone use during class while permitting it when necessary respects both the advantages and drawbacks of these devices, helping to create a more productive and secure school environment.

ai_draft_text: With remarkable advancements in science and genetics, society now faces a profound ethical dilemma: should parents have the right to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent diseases, or should genetic modifications be banned to preserve natural human diversity? This debate centers around two main perspectives—one advocating for the benefits of genetic editing in eliminating hereditary diseases, and the other warning against the risks of diminishing human diversity and the potential for misuse.  Proponents of genetic editing argue that allowing parents to modify the genes of their unborn children can significantly reduce the burden of genetic diseases. Conditions such as Motor Neuron Disease (MND) and Huntington’s disease are devastating, often leading to severe physical and cognitive decline. By enabling parents to eliminate these genetic disorders before birth, children can be spared a lifetime of suffering and uncertainty. This preventative approach not only improves the quality of life for the individual but also relieves families and society from emotional and financial hardships associated with hereditary diseases.  On the other hand, opponents of genetic editing emphasize the importance of preserving natural human diversity. They argue that interfering with the human genome raises complex ethical questions and opens the door to potentially dangerous practices. For instance, if genetic editing is permitted to prevent diseases, where should we draw the line? Could parents start selecting traits such as gender to avoid gender-specific diseases, or modify skin color to reduce the risk of skin cancer? Such scenarios highlight concerns about creating a slippery slope that could lead to “designer babies” and exacerbate social inequalities. Furthermore, the long-term consequences of altering the human genome remain unknown, posing risks not only to individuals but to the genetic makeup of future generations.  In conclusion, parents should have the right to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent serious diseases like Motor Neuron Disease, as this technology offers a powerful means to protect future generations from avoidable suffering. However, it is essential that such practices are strictly regulated to prevent misuse and to safeguard the diversity and integrity of humanity. Careful oversight can ensure that genetic editing serves as a tool for health and well-being, rather than a means to impose subjective ideals on the next generation.
final_text: With the rapid advancements in genetic science, a profound ethical debate has emerged regarding whether parents should have the right to genetically edit their unborn children. This discussion centers on two primary perspectives, one that supports genetic modification to prevent diseases and relieve suffering, and another that argues that such interventions should be banned for the purposes of preserving natural human diversity. Both viewpoints raise important considerations about the ethics of  genetic science intervention and the role of it plays in human diversity and quality of life.  Proponents of genetic editing highlight the significant benefits it can bring, particularly in the prevention of debilitating diseases, such as Motor Neuron Disease (MND) and Huntington’s disease. Both are potential inherited genetic disorders that have devastating effects on individuals and their families. By allowing parents to edit the genes of their unborn children, these diseases could potentially be eradicated before birth, sparing children a life of fear and suffering. The ability to prevent such hereditary illnesses  improves the quality of life for current and future generations.  Conversely, opponents caution against the wide-scale use of genetic modifications, emphasizing the importance of preserving natural human diversity. They argue that if genetic editing is permitted, the boundaries of its application could easily become blurred, leading to ethically questionable practices such as selecting a child’s gender or physical traits like skin color.  Some may justify these choices by appealing to disease prevention such as selecting lighter skin to reduce the risk of skin cancer, however the long-term consequences and social implications of such interventions are unpredictable and potentially harmful. Moreover, these practices could contribute to new forms of inequality and discrimination, undermining the very diversity that enriches human society.  In conclusion, parents should have the right to genetically edit their unborn children, particularly when it comes to preventing serious diseases like Motor Neuron Disease and Huntington’s disease. Such interventions have the potential to protect future generations from immense suffering. However, it is crucial that genetic editing be tightly regulated to prevent misuse and to ensure that natural human diversity is respected. Striking a balance between scientific progress and ethical responsibility will be essential as we navigate this complex issue.

While it is undeniable that smartphones have become an integral part of daily life, the debate over whether public schools should ban them during the school day remains highly relevant. Smartphones can be a distraction and hinder academic performance, yet they also offer potential benefits such as facilitating emergency communication and supporting learning when used appropriately. Despite the positives, the negatives outweigh the benefits, making a strong case for banning smartphones in schools.  One primary reason for banning smartphones is the distraction they cause in the classroom. Students are easily tempted to check social media, play games, or text friends, which detracts from their focus on lessons and learning activities. This divided attention can lead to lower retention of information and a decline in overall academic performance. Teachers often struggle to maintain classroom discipline when students are preoccupied with their devices, which negatively impacts the learning environment for the entire class.  Another significant concern is the impact of smartphones on students’ mental health and social skills. Constant connectivity can increase anxiety, reduce face-to-face interactions, and contribute to cyberbullying. When smartphones are banned, students are more likely to engage directly with peers and focus on developing interpersonal skills critical for their future success. This healthier social engagement fosters a positive atmosphere that supports both emotional well-being and academic growth.  On the other hand, proponents argue that smartphones can be useful tools for learning and emergency situations. Limited, supervised use could allow students to access educational apps or contact parents if necessary. However, these benefits can be achieved through school-provided technology or controlled communication channels without the distraction and risks that personal smartphones bring into the classroom.  In conclusion, while smartphones offer some advantages, the potential distractions and negative effects on students’ focus and mental health justify banning them during the school day. By eliminating smartphones, schools can create a more conducive environment for learning and personal development, ensuring that students gain the most from their education in this digital age.

ai_draft_text: The advent of genetic editing technology has sparked significant ethical debates, particularly surrounding the question of whether parents should have the right to genetically modify their unborn children to prevent diseases. While the desire to eliminate suffering is understandable, intervening in the natural genetic makeup of humans is an unnatural act that raises profound moral and practical concerns. Humans should not attempt to control or interfere with natural biological processes that have evolved over millennia.  One of the primary reasons for caution is the uncertainty surrounding the long-term risks of gene editing. Despite advances in science, we do not yet fully understand the potential consequences of altering human DNA. Genetic changes made today could have unforeseen and possibly detrimental effects on future generations, potentially introducing new health problems or reducing genetic diversity in unpredictable ways. The complexity of the human genome means that even well-intentioned modifications carry risks that science has not yet fully mapped.  Furthermore, banning genetic modifications in unborn children would help preserve natural human diversity, which is vital for the resilience and adaptability of our species. Genetic variation plays a crucial role in preventing widespread vulnerability to diseases and environmental changes. By allowing nature to take its own course, we honor the evolutionary processes that have shaped humanity and maintain the rich genetic tapestry that contributes to the strength and uniqueness of individuals and populations.  Moreover, there are ethical and potentially safer alternatives to preventing diseases in unborn children. Prenatal screenings, improved maternal healthcare, and advances in medical treatments offer ways to reduce the incidence and impact of genetic diseases without resorting to genetic editing. These methods respect human life and diversity while still addressing health concerns.  In conclusion, while the impulse to eradicate disease is noble, parents and society should refrain from genetically editing unborn children. The risks and ethical implications are significant, and preserving natural human diversity is essential. Instead, we should seek more ethical and tested approaches to support the health of future generations.

On one hand, genetic editing offers a promising solution for parents who are at risk of passing on severe genetic diseases to their children . For example, conditions such as cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anemia, and Huntington's diseases are caused by specific genetic mutations that could potentially be corrected through genetic editing. By eliminating  these mutations, parents could ensure that their children are born without debilitating conditions, improving their quality of life and reducing the emotional and financial burden on families.  Furthermore, the ability to prevent genetic disease could also reduce treating these conditions, benefiting society as a whole.  However, the use of genetic editing to prevent disease also raises significant  ethical concerns. One of the primary worries is that genetic editing could lead to slippy slope where parents begin to select for nonmedical traits , such as physical appearance or intelligence rather than just focusing on preventing diseases.

outline_text: Employers requiring workers to return to the office several days a week benefits and drawbacks  Benefits include increased supervision and accountability on certain work tasks and projects, an improvement in worker productivity and morale based on more motivation and being ready to work, and a sense of separation between work and home life.  Drawbacks include a lack of flexibility, expensive commuting costs, and potentially lower productivity due to exhaustion.  It is important to make sure that the benefits and drawbacks are carefully considered before making a policy to allow or disallow remote work.
human_draft_text: Allowing people to work from home full time versus requiring people to work in the office at least some time or full time is an interesting debate. It is important to allow people to choose what they feel is best for them, but at the same time, workers should be at least somewhat responsible for how they perform at the company as they are paid a significant amount of money to do their jobs in a way that allows the company to grow. Workers need to be able to produce more than it costs for the company to hire them, and the company needs to be able to monitor how each worker performs in order to be able to maintain profits. If people have to work in the office at least some time, then it is easier for the company to monitor them as they can see patterns of whether or not someone has been able to complete their tasks on time in the office or whether they are significantly faster in the office than at home or slower in the office than at home. People may also be more motivated at work if they have to work in the office at least a few days a week because they can separate work and personal life by being in different locations, which may prevent them from being distracted at work or may allow them to fully separate themselves at home when the work day is over. On the other hand, if people are allowed to work from home all the time, then they may take advantage of this when they feel like they cannot be monitored by intentionally working slower than they would at the office or by working large amounts of overtime which may not be possible in an office setting. Managing employees productivity by monitoring instead of giving them full freedom however also has some drawbacks. For example, people may feel like they cannot be as productive at the office because they have to spend time commuting which can also be expensive and leave them feeling like they cannot make it through the day compared to if they were allowed to work from home. They may also feel like they cannot work as flexibly, which may cause them to not be able to work and balance personal or family life at the same time compared to if they have to work at home. If people spend their time complaining at the office, they are not likely to be as productive compared to if they were allowed to work at home. However, it is important to ensure that both the advantages and disadvantages of working from home full time versus having to come to the office a few days a week are considered before a company decides on a remote work policy. A good compromise would be a pay difference between the same jobs if they are worked at from home full time compared to if they were worked at in the office at least some of the time, as it may motivate more people to come to the office without forcing them to.

outline_text: Many employers report that employees boast improved productivity and better job satisfaction when they use the option to work remotely, but is that really true? Anecdotally, all of the workers I know that work from home spend significant portions of their day doing chores, shopping online, and simply browsing social media on the phone. If this is remotely true for even a significant portion of others, why is the productivity increasing? Simply put, employees were never putting in good effort in the office. These employees seem to operate in bursts, alternating between almost 100% breaks and extremely concerted effort. So, is this truly the result of WFH scheduling? Likely not. In fact, this observation could be an argument for a more militant style of management and a condensed work week, resulting in further increases in employee pay per hour.
ai_draft_text: The debate over whether large employers should require workers to return to the office several days a week or allow fully remote schedules by default has gained significant attention in recent years. Many employers report that employees exhibit improved productivity and better job satisfaction when given the option to work remotely. However, this notion warrants closer scrutiny to understand if these claims truly reflect the reality of remote work.  Anecdotally, many workers who work from home spend considerable portions of their day engaged in non-work-related activities such as doing household chores, shopping online, or browsing social media. If such behavior is common among a substantial number of remote employees, it raises an important question: how is overall productivity apparently improving under these conditions? One plausible explanation is that employees were not fully committed or productive even while working in traditional office settings. Instead, workers might naturally operate in bursts of intense focus interspersed with lengthy periods of low or no productivity. This pattern likely persisted regardless of the work environment.  Therefore, it is questionable to attribute improvements in productivity and job satisfaction solely to remote work schedules. Instead, the data may reveal a deeper issue regarding employee engagement and management practices. If productivity fluctuates significantly regardless of location, it suggests a need for more structured and effective management approaches. For instance, adopting a more disciplined and focused management style, coupled with a condensed workweek, might better optimize employee output. Such changes could allow employees to concentrate their efforts into shorter, highly productive work periods, which could, in turn, justify higher pay rates per hour worked.  In conclusion, while remote work offers undeniable flexibility and certain benefits, the reported increases in productivity may not stem directly from employees’ location shifts. Instead, it may underscore longstanding patterns of work behavior and a management style in need of reform. Large employers should carefully consider these factors before deciding whether to mandate office returns or embrace fully remote schedules as the default.

The reasons for this are primarily rooted in the issues of distraction, addiction, and misuse.  Firstly, smartphones are highly addictive and a major source of distraction within the learning environment. This distraction not only hampers individual academic performance but also disrupts the overall classroom atmosphere. Teachers often struggle to keep students engaged when their attention is divided between the lesson and their devices.  Secondly, the misuse of smartphones by students presents a serious problem. Aside from distraction, smartphones can facilitate access to inappropriate content such as pornography, which is harmful to young minds. Moreover, these devices can be channels for spreading misinformation or engaging in cyberbullying, both of which can have detrimental effects on the school community. Allowing unrestricted smartphone use during school hours essentially opens doors to these negative behaviors.  As a viable alternative, schools could permit the use of tablets such as iPads for educational purposes. These devices can be controlled and restricted to ensure they are used solely for learning, minimizing distractions and misuse. Unlike personal smartphones, tablets provided by schools are less personal and can be monitored more effectively, which helps maintain a productive learning environment. Banning smartphones in public schools and utilizing restricted tablets for educational use strikes a balance between leveraging technology and maintaining focus and safety in the classroom. This approach best supports the educational mission of schools to foster a positive and effective learning environment.

Today, however, student loans sometimes feel like a game of Monopoly—where debt is reset or forgiven, potentially eroding the sense of accountability that once guided financial decisions. In conclusion, rather than broadly expanding student-loan forgiveness programs, the government should prioritize thoughtful, moderate reforms. outline_text: Title: Return to Office or Fully Remote Work: An Analysis Introduction: The Covid-19 pandemic introduced new work schedules, with many employers embracing remote work as opposed to the traditional office jobs. (Thesis statement) - I think large employers should embrace a hybrid schedule whereby workers can operate from home and office to optimize worker productivity and promote a healthy work-life balance. First point: A hybrid model ensures that employees enjoy a healthy work-life balance Second point: A hybrid model can help employees remain more productive Conclusion: A hybrid model is the best way to ensure employees remain happy and productive in today's work realities.
ai_draft_text: Return to Office or Fully Remote Work: An Analysis  The Covid-19 pandemic drastically transformed the traditional work environment, prompting many employers to adopt remote work to maintain business continuity. As the world gradually emerges from the pandemic, a pressing question arises: should large employers require workers to return to the office several days a week, or allow fully remote schedules by default? I believe the optimal approach lies in embracing a hybrid schedule, allowing employees to work both from home and the office. This model not only enhances productivity but also promotes a healthy work-life balance.  First and foremost, a hybrid work model supports a healthy work-life balance for employees. By splitting their time between the office and home, workers can better manage personal responsibilities alongside their professional duties. This flexibility reduces stress, lowers burnout rates, and contributes to overall job satisfaction. Employees can schedule time for family, exercise, or hobbies without compromising their work commitments. In contrast, strictly office-based schedules often demand long commutes and rigid hours, while fully remote work can sometimes blur the boundaries between work and personal life, leading to overwork.  Secondly, a hybrid model can significantly boost employee productivity. Working from home several days a week allows employees to leverage quieter environments free from typical office distractions, enabling them to focus on deep work tasks. Conversely, regular in-office days facilitate collaboration, brainstorming sessions, and spontaneous interactions that foster creativity and team cohesion. This balance ensures employees remain engaged and connected while performing at their best. Research has shown that employees in hybrid settings often report higher productivity levels compared to those working exclusively in one environment.  In conclusion, adopting a hybrid work schedule offers large employers a balanced solution that addresses the challenges of both fully remote and fully in-office models. By combining the benefits of flexibility and face-to-face collaboration, a hybrid approach ensures that employees remain happy, motivated, and productive in today’s evolving work landscape. As such, large employers should consider making hybrid schedules the default work arrangement moving forward.

outline_text: Introduction: talking about the hooks, rising education debt crisis in the  us, background overview of the current student loan debt situation.  Thesis statement will be, the federal government should broaden student loan forgiveness programs to alleviate the burden of education debt and promote economic growth. Talking about the economic benefits, increased disposable income, boost to GDP Social benefits, reduced inequalities, increased access to education Counterargument and response, alternative solutions Conclusion, recap main points.
ai_draft_text: The rising education debt crisis in the United States has become an urgent issue affecting millions of Americans. With student loan debt surpassing $1.7 trillion, many individuals struggle to manage their financial obligations, which in turn impacts the broader economy and society. The increasing burden of education debt calls for decisive action from the federal government. Given the widespread effects of this crisis, the government should broaden student loan forgiveness programs to alleviate the burden of education debt and promote economic growth.  One key reason to expand loan forgiveness is the economic benefit it provides. When borrowers are relieved of overwhelming debt, they gain increased disposable income that can be spent on goods, services, and investments. This boost in consumer spending can stimulate economic growth and help expand the nation’s GDP. Additionally, reducing education debt can unlock opportunities for entrepreneurship, homeownership, and retirement savings, which contribute to a more robust economy over the long term.  Beyond economic advantages, broadened loan forgiveness programs have significant social benefits. Student loan debt disproportionately affects low-income and minority communities, exacerbating existing inequalities. By easing this financial burden, more individuals can access higher education without the fear of crippling debt, promoting social mobility and equity. Broader forgiveness programs can thus work as a tool to reduce educational disparities and create a more inclusive society with equal opportunities for success.  Some argue that alternative solutions, such as lowering tuition costs or increasing financial literacy, might better address education debt. While these are important measures, they do not provide immediate relief to those currently burdened by debt. Loan forgiveness programs address the urgent needs of millions while policies to reduce future debt can be implemented in parallel.  In conclusion, broadening student loan forgiveness programs offers crucial economic and social benefits that can help alleviate the mounting education debt crisis. By adopting expanded forgiveness initiatives, the federal government can foster economic growth, reduce inequalities, and enhance access to education for all Americans.

outline_text: Talk about the tragedy of the woolly mammoth going extinct and argue that human overhunting is as much to blame for their decline as any environmental factors. Explain that they could invigorate local ecosystems that are lacking in large herbivores and that it could lead to an improvement in biodiversity. Finally, conclude with the fact that we have already been responsible for so much destruction in the world that it's only right that we take accountability to create and repair this.
ai_draft_text: The extinction of the woolly mammoth stands as a poignant tragedy in the history of our planet’s wildlife. Once roaming vast stretches of the Earth, these majestic creatures were driven to extinction not merely by natural environmental changes but significantly due to human overhunting. Early humans, through relentless hunting and habitat disruption, hastened their decline, making the woolly mammoth’s disappearance a direct consequence of human activity as much as natural factors. This recognition places a moral responsibility on us to consider the possibility of bringing them back through genetic engineering.  Reviving the woolly mammoth could offer substantial ecological benefits, particularly in regions where large herbivores have long been absent. Mammoths played a crucial role in maintaining the balance of their ecosystems by grazing on vegetation, which helped sustain grasslands and supported diverse animal communities. Their return could invigorate these local ecosystems, promoting healthier and more diverse habitats. Increased biodiversity resulting from their presence could enhance ecosystem resilience, helping to combat challenges such as climate change and habitat degradation.  Moreover, humanity has already been responsible for unprecedented destruction and loss of species throughout history. Given this, it is only fair and just that we take accountability—not only by preventing further harm but also by actively working to repair and restore what has been lost. Genetic engineering presents a unique opportunity to right past wrongs by reintroducing species like the woolly mammoth and restoring ecological balance. While debates about the ethics and risks of de-extinction persist, embracing this responsibility reflects a commitment to healing the planet and acknowledging our role as stewards of nature.  In conclusion, the tragedy of the woolly mammoth’s extinction, largely caused by humans, compels us to consider their revival. Doing so could rejuvenate ecosystems and improve biodiversity, fulfilling our ethical duty to restore the natural world we have so deeply impacted.

outline_text: There should not be a blanket requirement for all employees to return to office several days a week, many employees are more productive outside f the office and others have no reason to stay in the office. In many cases employees can more effectively manage their time than their managers and the introduction of location restrictions can impede on the flow of said employees. A more balanced approach to this would be to measure individual employee performance at home vs in office would be more effective in the decision making process of rather to bring them back in or not. All in all if an employee is doing well at home the employers' top priority should be providing that employee with the right equipment or tools to do their job most effectively and they should only reevaluate the underperformers.
ai_draft_text: In recent years, the question of whether large employers should require workers to return to the office several days a week or allow fully remote schedules by default has become increasingly relevant. While some argue that in-person collaboration and supervision are essential, a blanket requirement for all employees to return to the office is neither practical nor beneficial. Many employees demonstrate higher productivity when working remotely, and for some, remaining in the office does not offer any substantial advantage.  One key reason against requiring all employees to return is that individual work styles vary greatly. Some employees thrive in the quiet, personalized environment of their homes, free from common office distractions. Others may have personal circumstances, such as caregiving responsibilities or long commutes, that make remote work more practical. Moreover, many employees have proven capable of managing their own time effectively without direct oversight. Imposing location restrictions can hinder their natural workflow and decrease overall efficiency.  A more balanced and productive approach would be to evaluate each employee’s performance both at home and in the office. Rather than enforcing a one-size-fits-all policy, employers should focus on outcomes and results. If an employee consistently meets or exceeds expectations while working remotely, there is little justification for mandating a return to the office. In such cases, the employer’s priority should shift to equipping the employee with the necessary tools and technology to maintain or enhance their productivity.  Conversely, if an employee underperforms in a remote setting, it may be appropriate to reevaluate their arrangement and consider office attendance as a potential solution. This individualized approach respects the diversity of work styles and personal circumstances while maintaining a focus on organizational goals.  In conclusion, large employers should avoid blanket mandates requiring office presence several days a week. Instead, decisions should be based on individual performance, prioritizing employee productivity and well-being. Supporting remote employees with the right resources will enable companies to thrive in a flexible, modern work environment.

The growing interest on student loans is a significant problem because it traps borrowers in a cycle of debt. As interest accumulates, graduates may find themselves owing much more than they initially borrowed, making it challenging to make meaningful progress toward paying off their loans. At the same time, many recent graduates face numerous other financial responsibilities. Addressing the student debt crisis through broader forgiveness is a necessary step to support millions of Americans and promote a more equitable society. Therefore, expanding student-loan forgiveness should be prioritized over other approaches to managing education debt.

outline_text: Genetic editing is one of the toughest moral questions we face in the field of medicine going forward. Whilst the potential to prevent diseases is something that is undeniably positive, the danger is that once we cross the moral boundary of genetic editing in the womb it will lead to less ethical uses. Should it be used to choose characteristics for an unborn baby? That would begin to heavily impact human diversity and could be used for pre-emptive ethnic cleansing. The concern, therefore, is not the treatment of disease, but the further consequences of opening Pandora's Box. We also have to question the extent to which we want to further extend human lifespans, something which is already putting enormous pressure on economies and health systems worldwide.
ai_draft_text: Genetic editing represents one of the most challenging ethical dilemmas in modern medicine. On one hand, the ability to modify the genes of unborn children holds immense promise for eradicating hereditary diseases and improving quality of life. On the other hand, it raises profound moral questions about the limits of human intervention and the potential consequences of altering the natural course of human development.  The undeniable benefit of genetic editing lies in its capacity to prevent debilitating illnesses before birth. Conditions such as cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anemia, and Huntington’s disease could potentially be eliminated, sparing countless individuals from suffering and reducing the burden on healthcare systems. From this perspective, allowing parents the right to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent disease seems not only reasonable but ethically imperative.  However, the concern extends far beyond disease prevention. Once genetic editing in the womb becomes commonplace, society risks crossing a moral boundary that could lead to far less ethical uses. The ability to choose specific physical traits, intelligence levels, or other characteristics may soon follow, eroding the natural diversity that defines humanity. Such practices could even pave the way for pre-emptive ethnic cleansing, where genetic modifications are employed to diminish or eliminate certain cultural or ethnic traits, leading to homogenization rather than diversity.  Moreover, these possibilities raise broader questions about the implications for human lifespans and societal structures. Extending life artificially already places considerable strain on economies and healthcare resources globally. Further genetic interventions could exacerbate these pressures, creating challenges that we are not yet equipped to manage.  In conclusion, while the potential to prevent disease through genetic editing is a compelling justification for its use, the broader ethical and societal consequences are deeply troubling. To preserve natural human diversity and avoid the dangerous precedent of unchecked genetic manipulation, it is crucial to approach this technology with caution, if not outright restriction. Balancing hope for medical advancement with vigilance against moral overreach remains one of the most pressing tasks for our generation.

If parents could prevent their child from inheriting a debilitating genetic disease, they might give them a healthier start in life, free from certain suffering or limitations. Moreover, reducing the occurrence of genetic diseases could lessen the burden on healthcare systems by lowering the demand for lifelong medical care and interventions. Additionally, the ethical boundaries between preventing disease and selecting non-medical traits such as hair or eye color are blurred, risking a slippery slope towards eugenics. Society would need clear, enforceable regulations to distinguish legitimate health-related interventions from enhancements driven by personal or aesthetic preferences. The prospect of “designing” humans could diminish acceptance of differences and reduce genetic variation in the population.  In conclusion, while genetic editing offers hopeful possibilities for preventing suffering and improving health, it also introduces complex ethical dilemmas and potential social risks. A balanced approach that carefully regulates its use, emphasizing disease prevention while guarding against misuse and inequality, is essential as this technology advances. Society must navigate these challenges thoughtfully to ensure that scientific progress benefits all without compromising core human values.

ai_draft_text: The debate over whether large employers should require workers to return to the office several days a week or allow fully remote schedules by default has become increasingly relevant in today’s evolving work landscape. While remote work offers undeniable flexibility, compelling reasons suggest that a structured return to the office can be more beneficial for companies and employees alike.  One of the main advantages of office work is the enhancement of teamwork. Being physically present fosters clearer communication and more spontaneous collaboration, which are often limited in virtual settings. Face-to-face interactions help build stronger relationships among colleagues, contributing to a robust company culture that can be difficult to cultivate remotely. Additionally, supervision and feedback become more straightforward in an office environment, enabling managers to support employees effectively and ensure productivity.  That said, remote work presents certain challenges. It can hinder teamwork by reducing informal interactions and shared experiences that often spark creativity and cohesion. For some employees, working from home may also lead to feelings of isolation and disengagement, negatively impacting morale. Conversely, insistence on full-time office work might lower job satisfaction for those who value flexibility, potentially affecting retention.  A promising middle ground is the hybrid schedule, which combines the benefits of both approaches. By designating specific days for in-office attendance, companies can maintain structured opportunities for collaboration and cultural reinforcement while allowing employees the flexibility to work remotely on other days. This balance can optimize productivity and employee well-being alike.  In conclusion, large employers should prioritize a hybrid model that requires workers to return to the office several days a week while preserving remote work options. This approach leverages the advantages of in-person interaction and supervision without sacrificing the flexibility that modern employees increasingly value. Ultimately, a balanced strategy supports stronger teamwork, clearer communication, and a healthier company culture.

Ultimately, requiring some in-office presence fosters stronger teamwork and communication, stronger company culture, and easier supervision while also allowing flexibility through hybrid schedules. From a managerial perspective, office work also allows for easier supervision and immediate feedback, helping maintain productivity and align goals more effectively.  A goodl middle ground is a hybrid schedule, where employess split their time between the office and home. This way, companies keep the benefits of the in-person teamwork while still offering flexibilty  However, it is important to acknowledge the challenges associated with both remote and office work. Remote work can sometimes reduce the frequency and quality of team interactions, leading to feelings of isolation and disconnection. Such a strategy harnesses the benefits of in-person collaboration and supervision while honoring employees’ need for flexibility, ultimately fostering a more productive and engaged workforce.

ai_draft_text: In many cities, the use of gas-powered leaf blowers has become a common practice for maintaining clean and tidy outdoor spaces. However, these machines generate significant noise and air pollution, raising the question of whether cities should ban them or leave equipment choices to homeowners and landscapers. While personal responsibility is important, the negative impacts of gas-powered leaf blowers on public health and the environment suggest that cities should consider restricting their use.  One of the most pressing concerns associated with gas-powered leaf blowers is the excessive noise they produce. The loud operation of these machines can disturb the peace of neighborhoods and cause stress and discomfort to residents. Constant exposure to such noise pollution can have unhealthy effects, including increased blood pressure, sleep disturbances, and reduced overall well-being. In this sense, the noise created by gas blowers is not just a minor inconvenience but a serious public health issue that affects many people in the surrounding environment.  In addition to noise, gas-powered leaf blowers contribute to air pollution by emitting harmful gases and particulate matter. When people inhale polluted air, they risk developing respiratory diseases such as asthma, bronchitis, and other lung conditions. These health risks are especially concerning for vulnerable groups like children, the elderly, and those with preexisting health problems. The pollution caused by gas blowers not only harms individual health but also damages the broader environment, contributing to air quality degradation and climate change.  While it is true that individuals should be responsible for the choices they make regarding the equipment they use, personal responsibility alone may not address the wider community impact. Wise decision-making means recognizing the consequences of one’s actions on others and the environment. By banning gas-powered leaf blowers, cities would encourage the use of quieter and cleaner alternatives, fostering a healthier environment for all residents.  In conclusion, the noise and pollution caused by gas-powered leaf blowers present significant challenges to public health and environmental quality. Although homeowners and landscapers should be mindful of their choices, city-wide bans on gas-powered leaf blowers are a necessary step toward protecting community well-being and promoting sustainable practices. Such measures would create quieter neighborhoods and cleaner air, benefiting everyone in the long run.

human_draft_text: Gene editing technology is advancing fast, nand many people are asking if parents should be allowed to edit their unborn child's genes to prevent diseases. At first this might seem like a good idea, I mean who wouldn't want to stop a child from suffering?  But when we think deeper, editing human embryos could cause serious problems. It could change how we see life, reduce human diversity, and created even bigger gaps between the rich and poor. That's why I believe we should now allow the genetic editing of unborn children.  First of all, editing a child's genes before they are born turns life into something that can be designed, like a product. Parents could start choosing not just health related changes but also things liuke appearance, intelligence or talents. This could lead to the future where people are expected to be "perfect" before they're even born. Every child deserves to be accepted for who they are, not for how their genes were picked.  Another big issue is the loss of genetic diversity. Human differences are what makes us strong as a species. By removing genes we think are "bad" we might also lose traits which could be important for the fututre. We don't fully understand how all genes work together, so changing them could have unexpected sideeffects that could affect not just the child but future generations too. Without gene diversity we'd eventually get to a point where everyone is too similar and we've all seen what happens when relatives have children together, this could lead to the end of the human race, or at least how we know it now.   Lastly gene editing is still not 100% safe. Mistakes in editing DNA can cause new problems that we may not even see until years or generations later. Once these changes are made they are passed on to future generations, and there is no way to undo them if something goes wrong.  In the end, while preventing disesases is a good goal, the risks of editing unborn children's genes are just too great. It could change what it means to be human, hurt our diversity and make society less fair. We should focus on treating diseases after birth and improving healthcare not trying to control how humans are made.
final_text: Gene editing technology is advancing fast, and many people are asking if parents should be allowed to edit their unborn child's genes to prevent diseases. At first this might seem like a good idea, I mean who wouldn't want to stop a child from suffering?  But when we think deeper, editing human embryos could cause serious problems. It could change how we see life, reduce human diversity, and create even bigger gaps between the rich and poor. That's why I believe we should not allow the genetic editing of unborn children.  First of all, editing a child's genes before they are born turns life into something that can be designed, like a product. Parents could start choosing not just health related changes but also things like appearance, intelligence or talents. This could lead to the future where people are expected to be "perfect" before they're even born. Every child deserves to be accepted for who they are, not for how their genes were picked. While prenatal care aims to improve health rather than select traits, gene editing crosses ethical lines by allowing intentional human design beyond therapeutic goals. However, strict ethical guidelines could be established to restrict gene editing solely to preventing serious diseases, avoiding non-medical modifications, but even then these laws could be changed over time and still lead to designer babies. For example, previous technologies like cloning faced strict regulations initially, but loopholes and changing public opinion have led to ethical debates and enforcement difficulties over time. For example, the difficulty in enforcing international agreements on gene editing technologies highlights the risk that some countries might permit broader uses, undermining global ethical standards. This suggests that controlling gene editing solely for medical purposes could become problematic. For example, despite strict laws on drug use, enforcement remains inconsistent worldwide, illustrating how regulations may fail over time.  Another big issue is the loss of genetic diversity. Human differences are what makes us strong as a species. By removing genes we think are "bad" we might also lose traits which could be important for the future. We don't fully understand how all genes work together, so changing them could have unexpected side effects that could affect not just the child but future generations too. Without gene diversity we'd eventually get to a point where everyone is too similar and we've all seen what happens when relatives have children together, Reduced diversity from gene editing differs from inbreeding effects; however, loss of variation can still increase vulnerability to diseases. Geneticists warn that artificial selection through gene editing could decrease allelic variation crucial for adaptability, unlike natural genetic drift or inbreeding mechanisms. This could lead to the end of the human race, or at least how we know it now.   Lastly, gene editing is still not 100% safe. Mistakes in editing DNA can cause new problems that we may not even see until years or generations later. Once these changes are made they are passed on to future generations, and there is no way to undo them if something goes wrong.  In the end, while preventing diseases is a good goal, the risks of editing unborn children's genes are just too great. It could change what it means to be human, hurt our diversity and make society less fair. We should focus on treating diseases after birth and improving healthcare not trying to control how humans are made. While treating diseases after birth is important, preventing incurable genetic conditions before birth could reduce suffering significantly. However, given the risks and ethical concerns, any use of gene editing must proceed with caution and strict oversight.

outline_text: Introduction- What is genetic modification and what are the uses of genetic modification specifically how has it been used in preventing diseases in both children and adults before now  Paragraph 1- Benefits of genetic modification and how can it improve the quality of life in children  Paragraph 2- What are the drawbacks of genetic modification and how can it impact society now and in the future, especially for future unborn children. ai_draft_text: Genetic modification refers to the deliberate alteration of an organism’s DNA to achieve desired traits or to eliminate undesirable ones. In the realm of human health, genetic modification has been used to prevent and treat diseases by targeting specific genes responsible for hereditary conditions. Techniques such as gene therapy have shown promise in correcting genetic defects in both children and adults, potentially eradicating diseases like cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anemia, and certain forms of cancer before symptoms even arise. As technology advances, the possibility of editing the genes of unborn children to prevent hereditary diseases has become a topic of intense ethical and scientific debate.  The benefits of genetic modification are significant, particularly in how it can improve the quality of life for children who might otherwise inherit debilitating conditions. By removing or correcting faulty genes in embryos, parents could ensure their children are born free from serious illnesses, reducing suffering and medical costs associated with long-term treatment. This proactive approach could enhance overall health outcomes, increase life expectancy, and allow children to lead fuller, healthier lives. Moreover, genetic modification could potentially eradicate certain genetic diseases from the human population entirely, leading to a future where fewer people are burdened by hereditary conditions.  However, there are substantial drawbacks to consider. Genetic modification raises concerns about the long-term impact on society and natural human diversity. Altering the genetic makeup of unborn children might lead to unforeseen genetic complications that could affect future generations. Furthermore, it could exacerbate social inequalities if such technologies are only accessible to wealthy families, creating a genetic divide between economic classes. There is also the risk of diminishing the natural genetic variation that contributes to human resilience and adaptability, potentially making humanity more vulnerable to new diseases or environmental changes. Ethical concerns also arise around the idea of “designing” human beings, which challenges the principle of accepting and valuing natural human differences.  In conclusion, while genetic modification offers promising benefits in preventing disease, the risks to society and the preservation of natural human diversity are too significant to ignore. Therefore, genetic modifications on unborn children should be banned to maintain ethical standards and protect the integrity of human genetic diversity for future generations.

ai_draft_text: The federal government should cease expanding student-loan forgiveness programs and consider rescinding past forgiveness arrangements. In a democratic capitalist society, education debt represents a contractual agreement between the borrower and the lender—typically the government or private institutions—and should be honored as agreed upon from the outset. Forgiving such debt through government intervention undermines the principle of personal responsibility and jeopardizes the integrity of financial commitments that underpin the education system and broader economy.  Moreover, relying on government-led redistribution to address education debt is neither sustainable nor equitable. Forgiveness programs effectively shift the financial burden onto taxpayers, many of whom did not attend college or have already repaid their loans. This redistribution is a short-term fix that overlooks the root causes of high education costs and places undue strain on public resources. Instead of broadening loan forgiveness, policymakers should prioritize initiatives that foster economic growth and individual prosperity through improved labor conditions, reduced unemployment, and enhanced innovation.  Addressing education debt requires structural changes that transcend simple forgiveness. For instance, investing in workforce development programs can lower unemployment and help graduates secure higher-paying jobs to repay their debts. Encouraging innovation can create new industries and opportunities, bolstering economic resilience and personal financial stability. Additionally, education powerhouse institutions, which often possess sizable endowments, should bear increased responsibility for their operational sustainability. Requiring such institutions to rely more heavily on their endowments, rather than perpetually driving up tuition fees, would help stabilize education costs and reduce future student debt burdens.  In conclusion, rather than broadening student-loan forgiveness programs, the federal government should focus on strengthening economic fundamentals and promoting institutional responsibility. By doing so, it can address the education debt challenge more effectively and fairly, cultivating a sustainable system that rewards personal commitment and fosters growth for all.
