outline_text: 1. Introduction  2. Quality of Life - Effect on child and parents. - Future considerations related to physical and emotional well-being  3. Financial Implications of Care - Direct cost of parents to pay for care - Impact on the healthcare system as a whole  4. Morality vs Emotion - Fundamental reasons for having children - Ethical implications of genetic modifications - Personal right versus legal considerations.  5. Conclusion
human_draft_text: The topic of having the right to genetically edit their unborn child's DNA to prevent diseases is controversial.  The topic questions core beliefs of both humanity and ethics.  Ultimately, I believe a parent should be allowed the option to genetically edit their child's DNA in order to prevent terminal or debilitating diseases in order to maintain a quality of life for both the parents and child.  The first consideration revolves around quality of life.  This encompasses both the life of the parents and child.  For a parent to have to bear the financial, physical and emotional effects of caring for a child with a disease is unfathomable.  It's an added strain on the the already taxing duties that come with a healthy child, let alone one who is sick or crippled.  For the child, living with such diseases adds another element of difficulty on a physical, emotional and social level.  Children with diseases are often ridiculed or treated differently by their peers.  That the means are available to prevent these things from happening would be a relief for both parents and children alike.  The second point to mention are the financial costs of caring for a child with a disease.  These are ongoing costs that often require years and years of treatment.  In some cases, the treatments can be for the duration of the child's life.  Given that they have a disease limits their future earning potential. When taking these things into account, it would be a difficult journey for all involved.  Additionally, for parents who cannot afford treatment, often times it's the tax payers than need to fund care.  This places a burden on society which can be solved before it begins.  Lastly and perhaps most importantly is the conflict between what is morally right and what is emotionally right.  I believe that when a couple brings a child into this world, their goal is to give the child the best life possible.  It's a natural human desire.  To deny them the right to that, I would argue, is immoral in itself.  Certainly gene modification can be abused so I support regulations that dictate what is and is not acceptable.  It would only be allowed to prevent terminal or debilitating diseases and not simply to make a child taller, better looking or have blue eyes.  In conclusion, while there are valid arguments for both points of view, I believe it comes down to the parents and child.  Society can judge, but unless they walk in the shoes of those who have to live that life, they have no right to determine what can and cannot be done.  Every family should have the right or the ability to ensure they live a happy and productive life by any means available.
final_text: The topic of having the right to genetically edit their unborn child's DNA to prevent diseases is controversial.  The topic challenges fundamental ethical and human values.  Ultimately, I believe a parent should be allowed the option to genetically edit their child's DNA in order to prevent terminal or debilitating diseases in order to maintain a quality of life for both the parents and child.  The first consideration revolves around quality of life.  This encompasses both the life of the parents and child.  For a parent to have to bear the financial, physical and emotional effects of caring for a child with a disease is unfathomable.  It adds to the already challenging responsibilities of raising a healthy child, let alone one who is sick or crippled.  For the child, living with such diseases adds another element of difficulty on a physical, emotional and social level.  Children with diseases are often ridiculed or treated differently by their peers.  Having the means available to prevent these problems would be a relief for both parents and children alike.  The second point to mention are the financial costs of caring for a child with a disease.  These are ongoing costs that often require years and years of treatment.  In some cases, the treatments can be for the duration of the child's life.  Given that they have a disease limits their future earning potential. Research has shown that individuals with chronic illnesses often experience higher unemployment rates and earn on average 20-30% less than their healthy peers. When taking these things into account, it would be a difficult journey for all involved.  Additionally, for parents who cannot afford treatment, often times it's the taxpayers who need to fund care.  This places a burden on society which can be solved before it begins.  Lastly and perhaps most importantly is the conflict between what is morally right and what is emotionally right.  I believe that when a couple brings a child into this world, their goal is to give the child the best life possible.  It's a natural human desire.  To deny them the right to that, I would argue, is immoral in itself.  Certainly gene modification can be abused so I support regulations that dictate what is and is not acceptable. Critics argue that genetic editing could lead to unforeseen health risks or exacerbate social inequalities. However, with strict regulations limiting use to preventing serious diseases, these risks can be minimized while promoting well-being. For example, regulatory bodies could mandate extensive safety trials and restrict genetic editing to well-defined medical conditions, ensuring equitable access to prevent social disparities.  Genetic editing should only be permitted to prevent terminal or debilitating diseases and not simply to make a child taller, better looking or have blue eyes.  In conclusion, while there are valid arguments for both points of view, I believe it comes down to the parents and child.  Society can judge, but unless they walk in the shoes of those who have to live that life, they have no right to determine what can and cannot be done.  Every family should have the right or the ability to ensure they live a happy and productive life by any means available.

Smartphones have shortened attention spans and affected imaginations. While some studies suggest that smartphone use may contribute to shorter attention spans, others highlight potential benefits for creativity and information access, indicating a complex relationship.  Our young can no longer think for themselves as the thinking is done for them by the machines in their pockets.  There is no need for higher order thinking skills; our phones tell us how to feel about Gatsby etc.  A wonderful tool, of course, but how can the younger generations be expected to think critically and/or imaginatively when they are at the beck and call of the latest social media notification, likely about someone who is not even in the classroom? Broadening federal student-loan forgiveness programs is not just an act of financial relief; it’s a necessary step toward restoring hope and opportunity for so many hardworking people. Freed from overwhelming monthly payments, borrowers could invest in homes, start businesses, or save for the future—activities that stimulate economic growth. Student loan debt also exacerbates inequality by placing higher education out of reach for many lower-income and minority students. High costs and steep loans effectively discriminate against those who cannot afford upfront payment or do not have family financial support, perpetuating cycles of poverty and limiting social mobility. It’s time for the federal government to act decisively—not just to erase debt, but to unlock the true potential of our nation’s future. Forgiving student loans is more than policy; it’s a lifeline to dreams that should be within everyone’s reach.

human_draft_text: Parents should have the right to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent diseases - I believe this with every fibre of my being, and in less than 300 words you will too. Allow me to take you on a journey - one fraught with evolutionary mystique...  To all of my Darwinian friends; the ones who rush to point out the magnificent survival adaptations of of Earth's creatures. Take for example, they might say, the Peruvian Mango-Snake. So endangered was this snake (named and hunted for the exotic aroma of its skin) it was in fact thought extinct in the late 1680s. That was true until 2009 when a small group was discovered in a London-bound fruit crate - with just one small difference; the aroma was gone. Scientists concluded that the more neutral-smelling snakes were being selected at a greater rate due to their higher propensity for survival. human_draft_text: Given how much the world tipped on it's axis barely 5 years ago due to the COVID-19 pandemic, it's natural for certain things to still not yet feel the same as they once did. New pathogens, lockdowns & vaccines aside, prior to the pandemic it was essentially unheard of to be graced with the benefits of home working, whether fully remote or hybrid.   Now in the years after the pandemic, it's clear old ways of working don't fit the mold anymore and maybe never did in the first place. One of many delusions of a capitalist society is the idea you're only working if someone else can see you doing so, like a thwarted observer effect. We may be a while away from escaping the grips of capitalism, but permitted home working feels like a small victory in the right direction.   Most people can and will sing their praises from the rooftops for home working - at first it might have felt novel, strange and a bit of a fumble to get used to sitting in online meetings in pyjamas, but it's worth it to have that extra time for yourself and your family, instead of a dull hour log commute one way to do a job you can do perfectly well from bed if you so desired. It isn't the responsibility of an employee to rationalise extortionate office rents or leases, and personally I believe that's the only real reason big corporations insist on not adopting (at the very least a hybrid method of working.

It isn't the responsibility of an employee to rationalize extortionate office rents or leases, and personally I believe that's the only real reason big corporations insist on not adopting (at the very least) a hybrid method of working.   It isn't exactly a hard science to understand employees feel better when they feel their needs are met by their employer. When employees know they're trusted to do the work they're hired for as the adults they are, they're happier, retention is higher, turnover is lower and this essentially breeds a better, healthier and improved work force - without the overarching feeling of being shackled to a work desk, or having the all seeing eye of a boss hovering over your shoulder.   At the very least, hybrid working should be adopted by all office employers as standard, with the option to go fully remote if that's what works for individual employees or teams.

outline_text: Deciding to remove leaves from lawns and landscapes in the fall is a purely cosmetic decision. The underlying grass will actually grow better and thrive when insulated and fed with the rich nutrients the leaves provide. Also, insects and worms, among other things, use leaf cover on the ground to live in and breed. The statistics clearly show a massive decline in the insect population in America, accompanied by a large decline in the bird population that is undoubtedly connected.  The time saved by using a leaf blower is arguably fairly minimal. Using a rake or broom does not take a great deal of effort and they are guaranteed not to annoy neighbors.   There's also the matter of gas-powered leaf blowers emitting noxious gases into the air. While the amount is trivial compared to vehicle emissions, it nevertheless counts. And there's also the possibility that the wind carries the exhaust over to the neighbor's house, causing difficulty breathing and maybe even an asthma attack.

Using a rake or broom does not take a great deal of effort and they are guaranteed not to annoy neighbors. Eliminating leaf blowers will make little difference on a household level. But what about lawncare companies or municipalities? They have valid reasons to use leaf blowers, yes. It simply is not reasonable to expect someone to rake up miles of leaves. Perhaps some compromise could be reached where blowers remain allowed for municipal and commercial use but are banned for regular household purposes. Of course, many houses use lawn care companies and in turn leaf blowers, so the change may not be sufficient for some people who are adamantly opposed to the devices altogether. And there's also the possibility that the wind carries the exhaust over to the neighbor's house, causing difficulty breathing and maybe even an asthma attack.   There is little question that leaf blowers are a nuisance. But are they a necessary one? Must we tolerate them like we tolerate freight trains rumbling through and blaring their horns? Are they simply a part of modern life? The weight of the arguments for and against leans heavily into the no category. No, they are not necessary and it is reasonable to at least explore the idea of reducing their use if not outright banning them.

outline_text: Main idea- Extinction is a natural process and reviving species risks ecological imbalance and ethical issues -first, topic: genetic engineering could revive extinct species like woolly mammoths  -extinction is sad, but it is natural and part of maintaining ecological balance  -current ecosystems could be harmed by re-introduction of an extinct species  -ethically, it's questionable (unforseen consequences)  -doing this could disrupt natural evolution  -conclude- respect natural boundaries to preserve ecological stability and adhere to ethics
human_draft_text: Meeting a wooly mammoth up close sounds like an exciting possibility, and with new genetic engineering technologies, could easily become a reality in the near future. Unfortunately, as fun as the prospect sounds, some grave possible outcomes make the idea something that should be left as a sci fi plot line and nothing more. Reviving species is natural part of maintaining ecological balance. Think of worms and birds. Birds need worms to eat. If you added a new, major worm predator, birds might die off, which could in turn starve a larger predator. Entire ecosystems could be upended by the introduction of a previously extinct species. Beyond that, evolution could be disrupted by the introduction of a previously-dead species. If wooly mammoth's bred with elephants, an entirely new species could be produced and upend the natural progress of evolution. On an ethical level, the entire idea is very questionable. Brining a species onto an earth that isn't much like their original home habitat, with totally different plants, animals, insects, climate, and which is now primarily dominated by humans is inherently unkind. We cannot know what their experience will be like, we cannot know whether they would adapt seamlessly or die in agony due to modern viruses, bacteria, fungi, or some other organism that we cannot predict will harm them. Overall, the idea of introducing an extinct species is (understandably) tempting- it almost seems like the natural progression of our rapidly advancing abilities in genetic engineering. But we have to be very careful how we deploy that technology. We have a great deal of power to affect our world at this point, even crossing a line that some believe shouldn't be crossed by any human. But we must pause to think about how our decisions could turn out. In this case, the consequences could be devastating for us and the species as well.

Electric equipment, especially leaf blowers, are also much quieter than traditional gas-powered models. This lack of noise pollution can lead to improved quality of life for communities.  While the benefits are many, it is important to consider that a full ban of gas-powered equipment would be a hardship for many who have already invested in it and may not be able to afford the switch. To help alleviate this, cities might consider providing incentives for those who make the switch willingly, and offering buy out programs to help people upgrade their equipment without significant cost to them. Careful consideration should be given to the timeline for rolling out any changes, and abrupt change with short deadlines can cause resentment and may be damaging to the overall effort.   Overall, I believe that it is possible to move toward a more environmentally friendly and community positive solution that allows homeowners and landscapers to make adjustments and adopt new equipment at their convenience, while also moving in the right direction

final_text: As technology advances in the medical field, it is not uncommon for moral and ethical issues to arise. One such case surrounds the topic of genetic modification. In the near future, parents may have the opportunity to genetically edit their unborn children. Many argue that this idea is beneficial to help prevent disease while others frown at the idea and call it akin to 'playing God.' This essay will dissect these viewpoints and will explore whether parents should have the right to participate in this controversial act at all. This essay argues that while parental rights are important, genetic modification must be carefully regulated to prevent ethical abuses and social harm.   When discussing gene editing one of the first things that comes to mind is the potential to eliminate diseases. Many feel that genetic modification can prevent a child from suffering from debilitating, painful, lifelong diseases. Some even suggest that it is cruel to be made aware that your child might be born with an detrimental illness and not intervene when it is possible to do so. For example, genetic editing has the potential to reduce conditions like cystic fibrosis, though critics warn that unintended consequences and ethical concerns must be addressed. Others feel as though this is a very slippery slope. What could start as a way to reduce harm and banish disease could snowball into what might be considered modern-day eugenics. If people are given tools to eliminate certain genes, it is not difficult to imagine the potential risks that may occur if the technology falls into the wrong hands. Historical instances, such as forced sterilizations tied to eugenics movements, demonstrate how genetic technologies could be exploited unethically.  Overall, while there are many risks, I believe that parents should only be able to do so under very strict regulation and in specific cases. As with anything, excessive use of genetic modification can have negative consequences, so as long as we keep this in mind, parents should retain the right to do what is best for their future child.

ai_draft_text: In today's digital age, the presence of smartphones in schools has become a contentious issue. While some argue for their limited use for educational purposes and emergencies, I firmly believe that public schools should ban smartphones during the school day. The distractions posed by smartphones can significantly hinder students' learning, and their absence can foster better focus, social interaction, and equality among students.  One of the primary reasons to ban smartphones in schools is that they are a major source of distraction. Learning often requires sustained concentration, especially when students are grappling with challenging subjects. Smartphones offer an easy and tempting escape from the difficulty of focusing on lessons. Instead of engaging with the material, students may find themselves scrolling through social media, playing games, or texting friends. This distraction detracts from their ability to absorb new information and develop critical thinking skills, ultimately undermining their educational growth.  Moreover, banning smartphones encourages students to interact face-to-face, which is an essential part of social development. In a world increasingly dominated by digital communication, learning how to effectively communicate and collaborate in person is an invaluable skill. When phones are not an option, students are more likely to engage in meaningful conversations, build friendships, and develop empathy and cooperation. These social skills are crucial not only for success in school but also for personal and professional relationships later in life.  Additionally, the presence of smartphones in schools can exacerbate social inequalities. There is often a visible competition among students to have the latest and most expensive devices. This dynamic can create feelings of exclusion and inferiority among peers who cannot afford such phones, fostering an environment of judgment and anxiety rather than inclusiveness and mutual respect.  In conclusion, banning smartphones in public schools during the school day is beneficial for several important reasons. It helps students focus on their education, promotes better social interaction, and reduces socioeconomic disparities. By removing this distraction, schools can create a more effective and equitable learning environment where all students have the opportunity to succeed.

Instead of engaging with the material, students may find themselves scrolling through social media, playing games, or texting friends. This distraction detracts from their ability to absorb new information and develop critical thinking skills, ultimately undermining their educational growth but it also could distract other students, negatively affecting them.  Moreover, banning smartphones encourages students to interact face-to-face, which is an essential part of social development. In a world increasingly dominated by digital communication, learning how to effectively communicate and collaborate in person is an invaluable skill. When phones are not an option, students are more likely to engage in meaningful conversations, build friendships, and develop empathy and cooperation. These social skills are crucial not only for success in school but also for personal and professional relationships later in life.  Additionally, the presence of smartphones in schools can exacerbate social inequalities. There is often a visible competition among students to have the latest and most expensive devices. This dynamic can create feelings of exclusion and inferiority among peers who cannot afford such phones, fostering an environment of judgment and anxiety rather than inclusiveness and mutual respect.  In conclusion, banning smartphones in public schools during the school day is beneficial for several important reasons. It helps students focus on their education, promotes better social interaction, and reduces socioeconomic disparities. By removing this distraction, schools can create a more effective and equitable learning environment where everyone has the same chance for success.

outline_text: Employers should allow employees to continue with remote work arrangements indefinitely  There are benefits to this arrangement, because some workers are more efficient and effective while working remote. There's also evidence that remote work can have a positive impact on workers' mental health, because sometimes in-person work arrangements can cause conflict and stress  I also think that employers don't have sufficient reason to restrict people from working remote, and I think that this could effectively translate to discrimination against people who would do better with remote work for mental or physical health reasons   In general I think employers should embrace change and new approaches to work, instead of living in the past. If they want to make sure that they're remaining relevant and attracting the best employees, I think providing flexibility is key
human_draft_text: There's been a lot of talk around the merits of remote work, and whether the old way of working in-person is better for office workers and other professionals. I believe that remote work is essentially good, because it offers workers a lot more flexibility. This can be crucial for workers who have disabilities, or who are on the autism spectrum. This is the primary reason that remote work should be allowed to continue, because it is the right thing to do by people.  There are other benefits to remote work arrangements too. I think that employers who remain open to offering remote work will often find that they're attracting more applicants, because there's a growing number of people who value flexibility and the comforts of working from home. Allowing people to work from home will help keep employers relevant and competitive in the job market. I also believe that for lots of employees, their productivity would increase if they were allowed to avoid commuting. All of the travel time people spend is draining, and for some people they may show up to work already tired from their commute. In addition, being able to work from home would give people more time to sleep, which inevitably would have a positive impact on their health and productivity.  Finally, I also don't believe that employers have legitimate reasons to force their employees to return to the office. There is not concrete evidence that productivity or morale is improved when people work in the same physical workplace, and in fact there's evidence to the contrary. It's possible that the general push for in-office work is also motivated by the people who own office spaces, because if their properties are not being rented out then they're losing money, and the property values of their buildings are decreased. I don't think this is a legitimate reason to make people come back to offices, though, and I believe the most important thing is that employees have freedom and flexibility in how they work.

Guidelines should specify appropriate times and purposes for use, such as limiting devices to educational activities and emergency contact only. In conclusion, outright banning smartphones in public schools is not the best approach. Instead, with well-defined rules and oversight, limited smartphone use can support both learning and student safety. Embracing the responsible integration of technology prepares students for the future while addressing concerns about distractions and misuse.

outline_text: The way we work has drastically changed over the years. Remote work suits many roles and boosts productivity. ai_draft_text: The way we work has undergone a profound transformation over the years, especially with the advent of advanced technology that enables seamless communication and collaboration from virtually anywhere. In light of these changes, a crucial debate has emerged: should large employers require workers to return to the office several days a week, or should they allow fully remote schedules by default? Given the evolving nature of work and the benefits associated with remote arrangements, it is increasingly clear that mandating office presence is an outdated practice that does not align with modern productivity and employee preferences.  Remote work is well-suited to many roles, particularly those that rely heavily on digital tools and independent tasks. Employees who work remotely often report higher levels of job satisfaction and improved work-life balance, which in turn boosts productivity. The absence of daily commutes reduces stress and frees up time for employees to focus on their tasks. Furthermore, remote work allows for a more flexible schedule, enabling people to work when they feel most efficient. This autonomy can lead to greater output and creativity, benefiting both the employee and the employer.  On the other hand, the insistence on mandatory office returns frequently stems from traditional management styles that prioritized physical oversight and face-to-face supervision. These methods were developed at a time when remote work was neither feasible nor common. Today, such approaches may hinder innovation and employee morale, as they fail to recognize the capabilities afforded by current technologies. Most job roles in modern organizations do not require physical presence to ensure productivity, and clinging to old practices can result in unnecessary disruptions and dissatisfaction.  In conclusion, large employers should embrace fully remote schedules by default, allowing employees the flexibility to choose their work environment. This shift not only reflects the realities of contemporary work but also promotes greater productivity and well-being. Mandating a return to the office several days a week is an outdated approach that fails to leverage the advantages enabled by technological advancements and evolving workplace expectations.

The debate over whether public schools should ban smartphones during the school day or permit their limited use for learning and emergencies is multifaceted. On one hand, allowing limited smartphone use in public schools can significantly enhance the learning experience. Smartphones provide students with immediate access to vast amounts of information and educational resources. When students encounter difficulties understanding a concept or need quick clarification, they can use their devices to conduct research and find helpful explanations. This instant access to information can support classroom learning and encourage independent problem-solving. Furthermore, smartphones serve as vital tools during emergencies. They enable students to contact authorities or family members swiftly, ensuring safety and quick response in unforeseen situations.  On the other hand, smartphones in the classroom can be a major source of distraction. The temptation to check social media, play games, or text friends during lessons can divert students' attention away from the teacher and the educational material. Such distractions can negatively impact academic performance, as students may miss important information or fail to engage fully in classroom activities. Additionally, the presence of smartphones can disrupt the classroom environment, making it challenging for teachers to maintain order and focus.  In conclusion, while smartphones offer valuable benefits for learning and emergency communication, their potential to distract cannot be overlooked. Therefore, public schools should adopt a balanced approach by permitting limited use of smartphones specifically for educational purposes and emergencies. Setting clear guidelines and monitoring usage can help maximize the benefits while minimizing the drawbacks, ultimately supporting a productive and safe learning environment.

outline_text: The federal government should not only not broaden student-loan forgiveness programs, but should reverse course and eliminate any form of a student-loan forgiveness program.  Student loans are private contracts between two parties who agreed to certain terms.  Student loans are no different than mortgages or any other type of loan from a financial institution or from another person.  Therefore, if a student-loan forgiveness program exists, then it is only fair to expand such programs to every other kind of personal loan so everyone can benefit from their own mistakes.
ai_draft_text: The federal government’s approach to addressing education debt has been a topic of significant debate in recent years, particularly regarding the expansion of student-loan forgiveness programs. While some advocate for broadening these programs to alleviate the burden on borrowers, the government should not only refrain from expanding such initiatives but should actually reverse course and eliminate student-loan forgiveness programs altogether. The reasoning behind this position is grounded in the nature of student loans as private contracts and the broader implications of selectively forgiving debts.  Student loans are fundamentally private agreements between borrowers and lenders, governed by mutually agreed-upon terms and conditions. These loans are no different from mortgages, auto loans, or personal loans obtained from financial institutions or individuals. When a borrower takes out a student loan, they enter into a contractual obligation to repay the borrowed amount under specified conditions, just as they would with any other type of loan. Forgiving student loans essentially alters the terms of these contracts retroactively, undermining the principle that contracts are to be honored as agreed upon.  Moreover, if the government elects to provide forgiveness for student loans, it sets a precedent that could logically be extended to all other types of personal loans. It would be unjust to forgive one category of debt while forcing others to shoulder the full consequences of their financial decisions. Expanding debt forgiveness solely for education loans creates a disparity, potentially encouraging irresponsible borrowing behaviors and unfairly disadvantaging those who have responsibly repaid their own loans, often for non-educational purposes.  Instead of broadening student-loan forgiveness programs, the federal government should prioritize alternative methods to address education debt. These might include improving financial literacy, promoting affordable education options, and enhancing income-driven repayment plans. Such measures would help borrowers manage their debts responsibly without compromising the integrity of contractual agreements or creating unequal treatment among different types of debt.  In conclusion, student-loan forgiveness programs should not be expanded; rather, they should be eliminated to uphold fairness, maintain contractual integrity, and prevent inequitable treatment among borrowers. The federal government’s focus should shift toward responsible and sustainable solutions that address the root causes of education debt rather than relying on forgiveness that undermines financial accountability.

outline_text: Introduce the debate and state a thesis. A body that presents arguments and points that support the ban. ai_draft_text: The use of smartphones in public schools has sparked considerable debate among educators, parents, and policymakers. While some advocate for a complete ban on smartphones during the school day, others suggest that limited use for learning purposes and emergencies can be beneficial. This essay will examine both perspectives before concluding with a reasoned recommendation.  Proponents of banning smartphones argue that these devices are a major distraction in the classroom. Students often find themselves tempted to engage with social media, games, or texting instead of focusing on lessons, which negatively impacts academic performance. Additionally, smartphones can facilitate cheating during exams, undermining the integrity of assessments. There are also concerns about cyberbullying and the spread of inappropriate content, which can be exacerbated by unrestricted phone access during school hours. From this viewpoint, a ban would help create a more focused learning environment and promote better social interactions among students.  On the other hand, some argue that smartphones are valuable tools for learning when used responsibly. Many educational apps and resources are accessible via smartphones, allowing students to research information, collaborate on assignments, and engage with interactive content. Moreover, smartphones provide an important safety net during emergencies, enabling students to quickly contact parents or emergency services if needed. Advocates for limited use suggest that schools should implement clear policies that allow phones only for educational activities and urgent communication, balancing benefits with potential drawbacks.  In conclusion, while smartphones present both challenges and opportunities in the school setting, the negative impacts of unrestricted use cannot be ignored. A complete ban during the school day may promote better concentration and reduce distractions, but completely prohibiting phones may also limit access to helpful educational resources and emergency communication. Therefore, the most effective approach is to permit limited smartphone use under strict guidelines that prioritize learning and safety. This balanced policy would harness the advantages of technology while minimizing its pitfalls, fostering a productive and secure school environment.

It is natural for parents to want to shield their children from pain and hardship. Genetic editing for health reasons is essentially an advanced form of what medicine and vaccines have always aimed to do: protect and improve human well-being. It is an extension of our ongoing quest to combat illness and promote longevity.  Moreover, human diversity is vast and rich, encompassing countless traits beyond those related to disease. The natural variety in appearance, culture, personality, and talents will remain intact even if genetic diseases are minimized. In fact, disease itself cannot be considered a positive aspect of diversity; it causes harm rather than benefits. Therefore, genetic editing to prevent disease does not undermine human diversity but rather enhances our collective health and potential.  In conclusion, parents should have the right to use genetic editing to prevent diseases in their unborn children. This practice aligns with our natural drive to improve lives and does not threaten the rich tapestry of human diversity. Embracing this technology responsibly promises a future where fewer children suffer from preventable illnesses, allowing humanity to thrive in new and healthier ways.

Individuals are dealing with mental health impacts associated with a society that has become more fractured and individualistic, and each of these could be improved by as many employees as possible being allowed to work fully remote schedules by default.   Employees will benefit from saving money as they do not pay the costs associated with commuting. They also benefit from saving time as they don't lose time to a commute, and face reduced risk when they spend less time travelling long distances, and more time at home. With a better work life balance they have more time to exercise, engage in leisure activities and take care of themselves, their family and friends. This results in happier, healthier, more productive employees. These employees are also more likely to be better citizens, with more time to engage in activities like volunteering, helping out their neighbours and improving their local community.   Employers will benefit from reduced costs for operating a smaller physical office space, as they don't need one desk per worker every day of the week. This will also reduce associated operational costs, such as that for utilities, office furniture and consumable supplies. As the employees are happier, the employers benefit from having a happier, more productive workforce. Employers also will have an increased pool of talent to hire from as they can hire from across the country (or globally).  Society at large will benefit from reduced traffic on the roads, improving the commute time and reducing costs for those who cannot work from home, like healthcare workers, first responders and sanitation workers. Reduced traffic lowers pollution, and reduces road accidents, improving health for people living in and near large cities.  Small businesses benefit as they are able to be located in suburban areas with more reasonable rental costs, and be patronised by local people working from home. This allows the economy to become more diverse, as it is easier to start a small business. Communities become closer as people interact with their neighbours and local businesses more often, and build up connections and support networks.

human_draft_text: When considering whether or not to revive an extinct species through genetic engineering, one must consider the idea from multiple angles. Even if humans were given this sort of technology, should we utilize it? On the one hand, it could lead to breakthroughs in science hitherto undreamt of. On the other hand, it could have numerous ramifications with long-reaching effects. Therefore, human beings should not resurrect any extinct species because it could disrupt the natural order of things, put a strain on modern resources, and lead to severe potential ethical problems in the future.  While it is tempting to consider reviving an extinct species, to do so would go against the natural order of the world. Whether a species reaches extinction through their numbers dying out or a natural disaster, that is how things were meant to be. Reintroducing extinct animals would force them to adapt to a world that has left them behind, in addition to potentially introducing diseases that the current planet is not prepared or adapted for.  Additionally, introducing extinct species back into existence may put a strain on already existing resources. One could easily argue that the time and money spent on genetically engineering extinct organisms could be used to preserve endangered species currently facing extinction that can still be saved. Alternatively, the money could benefit any number of other beneficial or charitable causes.  Finally, reviving these animals opens a "Pandora's Box" of ethical concerns. The technology of genetically engineered animals could be commodified into a business, or utilized in a way that prioritizes profit over scientific achievement. Eventually, the technology could be used to genetically modify and engineer humans, which has unsavory implications, particularly where eugenics is concerned.  In the end, while recreating "Jurassic Park" does seem like it would be amazing, there are several factors to consider before we do so. We must consider the evolutionary effects of this action, how it would impact the current world we inhabit, and consider the potential ramifications something like this might cause. So for now, we should keep the wooly mammoths on ice.

outline_text: leading statement Parents ought to have the right to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent serious diseases if specific factors are taken into consideration including, when strict ethical guidelines, regulatory measures are outlined since gene editing can reduce overall human suffering without compromising the gene pool or diversity Introduction (I) Define gene editing outline any scientific and ethical/moral controversy/argument surrounding gene editing Thesis statement  Argument 1:  derive direct from thesis; prevention of diseases and suffering give examples conclude on importance in preventive healthcare  Argument 2: counterargument Threat to human diversity and ethics  Conclusion
ai_draft_text: Genetic editing, a revolutionary scientific advancement, allows for precise alterations to an individual’s DNA, offering the potential to eliminate hereditary diseases before birth. While this technology promises remarkable benefits, it also ignites intense ethical debates regarding its implications on human diversity and morality. The question arises: should parents have the right to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent diseases, or should such modifications be banned to preserve natural human diversity? Parents ought to have this right, provided that strict ethical guidelines and regulatory measures are in place, as gene editing can significantly reduce human suffering without compromising genetic diversity.  Gene editing involves modifying an organism’s genetic code to correct mutations or introduce beneficial traits. The CRISPR-Cas9 system, one of the most widely known methods, allows scientists to target and alter specific genes with unprecedented accuracy. Ethically, critics argue that genetic editing could lead to “designer babies,” exacerbate social inequalities, or diminish the natural variation that underpins human evolution. Nonetheless, the potential to prevent debilitating hereditary diseases like cystic fibrosis or sickle cell anemia presents a compelling case for responsible use.  The primary argument in favor of permitting gene editing lies in its ability to prevent suffering and advance preventive healthcare. When parents have the option to eliminate genetic disorders, the resulting individuals enjoy healthier, longer lives free from the burden of inherited conditions. For example, editing out the BRCA gene mutation could drastically reduce the incidence of hereditary breast cancer. Such interventions not only improve quality of life but also reduce healthcare costs and emotional strain on families and society.  Opponents contend that gene editing threatens human genetic diversity and raises profound moral questions about “playing God.” They worry that widespread use could lead to homogenization or discrimination against those with unedited genes. However, with rigorous ethical standards and regulations that restrict editing to serious medical conditions rather than cosmetic traits, these risks can be mitigated. This balance ensures preservation of diversity while harnessing the technology’s life-saving potential.  In conclusion, granting parents the right to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent diseases, under strict ethical and regulatory frameworks, offers a promising path to reducing human suffering. By focusing on genuine medical needs and maintaining oversight, society can embrace the benefits of gene editing without sacrificing the natural genetic diversity that enriches humanity.

ai_draft_text: Cities Should Ban Gas-Powered Leaf Blowers to Reduce Noise and Pollution  Gas-powered leaf blowers have long been a common tool in maintaining yards and public spaces, yet their negative impacts on communities and the environment are increasingly undeniable. For these reasons, cities should ban gas-powered leaf blowers in favor of cleaner and quieter alternatives to reduce both noise and air pollution.  One of the most significant issues with gas-powered leaf blowers is the extreme noise they generate. These machines produce sound levels that are often above the threshold of safe hearing, not only disrupting the tranquility of neighborhoods but also posing long-term hearing damage risks to the workers who operate them daily. The persistent mechanical roar shatters the peace in residential areas, affecting the quality of life for many.  In addition to noise pollution, gas-powered leaf blowers contribute to air pollution by emitting toxic fumes. These emissions include volatile organic compounds and nitrogen oxides that contribute to smog and climate change. Furthermore, the fumes pose serious health risks such as respiratory problems and increased incidence of asthma among residents, especially in urban areas with frequent use of these machines.  Fortunately, there are cleaner and more efficient alternatives available. Electric leaf blowers have become widely accessible and offer a much quieter operation without the harmful emissions of gas-powered models. With advancements in battery technology, electric blowers are also comparable in power and durability, providing an environmentally friendly replacement that benefits both users and the community.  Opponents argue that banning gas-powered leaf blowers could harm small landscaping businesses reliant on them for efficient work. However, cities can support these businesses through phased transitions, incentives, and discounts on electric equipment. Such measures ensure that small businesses can adapt smoothly while the community achieves greater environmental and health benefits.  In conclusion, the prohibition of gas-powered leaf blowers is a necessary step toward healthier, more sustainable cities. By reducing noise and air pollution and promoting cleaner alternatives, municipalities can protect public health and foster a better quality of life for all residents.

outline_text: I think we could definitely bring back animals that have gone extinct but there needs to be a risk assessment methodology applied which considers risks to other animals, people, the environment and the subject animal itself.  These assessments may also consider whether the extinction cause was evolutionary or an external factor such as human interference or a meteor or other factor.
human_draft_text: There are a large of species of animals which have gone extinct.  This may be due to evolutionary pressures or external factors such as human intervention or significant events such as meteors.  It is now possible using genetic technology to bring back extinct animals to life.  However this technology must be applied withing a robust and transparent risk management framework to ensure it is appropriately applied.  A risk management framework which assesses risk in terms of likelihood and consequence could be used to assess the risk to the subject animal (would the subject animal be expected to survive), humans (does the subject animal present a risk to human safety), to other animals (would the subject animal habitat intrude on existing animals' habitat) and the environment (would the subject animal have a detrimental impact on the existing environment).  By assessing each of these risks, documenting the process for transparency and making a sound and logical final assessment of risk, a decision can be reach regarding whether it is appropriate to bring an animal back from extinction.  Transparency also enables external oversight and review as well and open communication with the public.  A second phase to the assessment process could look at the possible benefits to bringing back an extinct species.  Once the risk has been assessed as acceptable, a range of benefits could be explored including benefits to the environment by enhancing broken ecosystems, benefits to other species by increasing diversity, benefits to agriculture or farming.  These could be assessed and a cost benefit analysis performed to quantify this benefit and to make a final assessment.  Failure to adopt this risk based process may result in species being brought back to life which have unanticipated and unintended consequences to the subject animal, humans, other animals and the environment.  This could have potentially disastrous consequences.
final_text: There are a large number of species of animals which have gone extinct.  This may be due to evolutionary pressures or external factors such as human intervention or significant events such as meteors. Understanding the specific causes of extinction is crucial because resurrected species may struggle to survive or disrupt current ecosystems if conditions have drastically changed since their disappearance. As mentioned previously, evolutionary factors, such as change in climate or the presence of predators, may have caused extinction, and these factors may still be present today which might mean the revived animal may once more go extinct. It is possible that bringing back extinct species may reintroduce them into environments that have changed and they are no longer adapted to.  It is now possible using genetic technology to bring back extinct animals to life.  However this technology must be applied within a robust and transparent risk management framework to ensure it is appropriately applied.  A risk management framework which assesses risk in terms of likelihood and consequence could be used to assess the risk to the subject animal (would the subject animal be expected to survive), humans (does the subject animal present a risk to human safety), to other animals (would the subject animal's habitat intrude on existing animals' habitat) and the environment (would the subject animal have a detrimental impact on the existing environment).  By assessing each of these risks, documenting the process for transparency and making a sound and logical final assessment of risk, a decision can be reached regarding whether it is appropriate to bring an animal back from extinction.  Transparency also enables external oversight and review as well as open communication with the public.  A second phase to the assessment process could look at the possible benefits to bringing back an extinct species.  Once the risk has been assessed as acceptable, a range of benefits could be explored including benefits to the environment by enhancing broken ecosystems, benefits to other species by increasing diversity, benefits to agriculture or farming.  These could be assessed and a cost benefit analysis performed to quantify this benefit and to make a final assessment.  Failure to adopt this risk based process may result in species being brought back to life which have unanticipated and unintended consequences to the subject animal, humans (such as death or re-extinction), other animals and the environment (such as habitat destruction or change). For instance, the introduction of invasive species like cane toads in Australia has caused significant ecological damage, illustrating the risks of reintroducing species without thorough impact assessment.  This could have potentially disastrous consequences.  For example, ongoing habitat destruction and climate change are evolutionary pressures that could re-endanger revived species if not addressed.

Without the distractions of office chatter, impromptu meetings, and frequent interruptions, many remote workers find they can focus more deeply on their tasks. They have greater control over their environment, allowing them to tailor their workspace to suit their preferences and work rhythms. As a result, employees often complete tasks more efficiently and with higher quality. In conclusion, given the benefits to employee well-being, productivity, and interpersonal connections, large employers should default to fully remote work schedules. Embracing remote work supports a happier workforce and a more dynamic, resilient organization in today’s modern world.

While the prospect of reviving these prehistoric creatures is fascinating, it is important to consider the ecological and safety implications. Extinct animals no longer have a natural place in the modern world ecosystem, and reintroducing them could cause significant disruption.  Ecosystems are delicate networks of species that have evolved and adapted together over long periods. The extinction of certain species has led to a rebalancing of the food chain, with modern animals finding new roles and sources of sustenance. Introducing extinct species like the woolly mammoth could upset this balance, competing with current species for resources such as food, water, and habitat. This competition might lead to the decline or displacement of existing species, causing a ripple effect throughout the ecosystem that could prove harmful overall.  Furthermore, humans have evolved in an environment free of many of the predators and megafauna that once roamed the Earth. Reintroducing large and potentially dangerous animals could pose new threats to human safety. Unlike simple wildlife encounters, these revived species might act unpredictably or aggressively, leading to increased risks in both urban and rural areas.  Additionally, the environment has changed significantly since species like the woolly mammoth roamed the Earth. Climate, vegetation, and landscapes have evolved, rendering former habitats unsuitable. Even with advanced genetic engineering, the chances of successfully sustaining these populations in modern times are questionable.  In conclusion, while the technology to bring back extinct species is impressive, the broader implications suggest we should respect extinction as a natural boundary. Rather than attempting to reverse extinction, efforts should focus on preserving the biodiversity that currently exists and ensuring the health of modern ecosystems. This approach prioritizes ecological balance and human safety over the allure of resurrecting the past.

Introduction/Argument: Cities should not ban gas-powered (or any) leaf blowers      -Briefly frame argument: We have much bigger problems to be working on with limited city government resources and      monies  Expand on argument/explain        -Would likely be used as precedent to ban other equipment-what if the future bans are not as reasonable?       -Majority of public unlikley to support-why not concentrate energies on one of the much larger problems we have?       -How much of an issue are leafblowers, really?  Conclusion      -restate arguments      -Make final points
ai_draft_text: Cities Should Not Ban Gas-Powered Leaf Blowers  In recent years, there has been growing debate over whether cities should ban gas-powered leaf blowers to reduce noise and pollution. While concerns about environmental impact and noise pollution are valid, cities should not implement such bans. With limited government resources and pressing urban challenges, focusing on leaf blowers diverts attention from far more significant problems faced by communities.  Firstly, banning gas-powered leaf blowers could set a precedent for restricting a wide range of equipment and tools used by homeowners and landscapers. Although leaf blowers may seem like an easy target, future bans might extend to other machines that are essential for property maintenance and business operations. This slippery slope could place unnecessary burdens on citizens and small businesses, potentially harming livelihoods and limiting personal freedoms. It is important to consider whether future restrictions will remain as reasonable as the proposed leaf blower ban.  Secondly, the majority of the public is unlikely to support a ban on gas-powered leaf blowers. Many people rely on these tools for efficient yard maintenance, and landscapers use them as vital equipment for their work. Given the limited capacity of city governments, it makes more sense to concentrate energy and resources on solving larger urban issues such as affordable housing, public safety, and infrastructure improvements rather than regulating relatively minor equipment.  Finally, the actual impact of leaf blowers, though not negligible, is minor compared to other sources of pollution and noise in cities. Gas-powered vehicles, industrial activity, and construction contribute far more heavily to air pollution and noise complaints. Addressing these larger-scale problems would yield more substantial benefits for urban health and quality of life.  In conclusion, while the concerns about gas-powered leaf blowers are understandable, banning them is not the best use of city resources or public attention. The risk of setting restrictive precedents, the limited public support, and the relatively minor impact of leaf blowers all suggest that cities should leave equipment choices to homeowners and landscapers. Instead, cities should focus their efforts on more pressing issues that affect the well-being of all residents.

human_draft_text: Introduction:  Student loans are provided by private institutions to students entering Universities that don't have the capital required to pay for their studies directly. Students apply for their funding during the University application process and aim to receive loans to cover tuition fees, which are paid to the University to cover course costs, and a maintenance loan, which covers the student's living costs. In the UK, the total student loan per year can reach well over £18,000 depending on the course, with 4-year courses for those from particular regions reaching beyond £50,000 for the total loan. This essay aims to take discuss whether student-loan forgiveness programs should be a priority method to addressing student debt, or whether other methods should be considered.  Main Body:  Forgiving student loads has wide-reaching economical ramifications, but these repercussions appear on both sides of the story. Whilst those companies providing the loans may lose out on revenue, the government often provides subsidies to said companies to keep the economy afloat and momentum high. Of course, this means the government then has to take the immediate financial burden, but as more people attend further education and develop specialist skills in key areas the country will benefit in due time.   This doesn't mean the country should decide to forgive all student loans immediately, there should be a reasonable process to decide for who, when and how loans should be forgiven. The UK currently has repayment plans in place where after 30 years, if the graduate hasn't earned over £30,000 per year, their loans are wiped. This is a flat plan across the board, but this needs addressing. As it allows for wealthier individuals to avoid earning this money on paper and therefore avoiding having to repay student loans, which in turn costs the entire country undue fees.  Conclusion:  Therefore, student loan forgiveness should not be a one-size fits all strategy, and should be means tested. Further action could be taking by addressing key areas of interest for the country and apply variable rates to tuition fees and supply grants to qualifications that require more graduates in the country.

outline_text: There are many alternative ways to power leaf blowers and some of these options are much better for the environment than using gas power. This article will outline the various pros and cons of using gas powered leaf blowers, discuss possible alternatives and what can be done to move people away from gas powered leaf blowers to those that use alternative forms of power.
human_draft_text: Gas powered leaf blowers are bad for the environment and using battery powered would be better due to them having no carbon emissions. Furthermore, gas powered engines are also noisy.  We know that gas powered engines in cars are a major cause of pollution, so it stands to reason that phasing them out and replacing them with other alternatives can benefit the environment. Just as with gas powered cars being noisier than battery powered cars, it is quite evident that this holds for leaf blowers too. Of course, noise from leaf blowers cannot be completely eliminated due to moving parts, but replacing a gas powered engine with a battery powered motor does reduce the amount of noise emitted.  So the argument so far is that battery powered motors are less polluting and quieter than gas powered engines but there are further arguments in favour of battery powered leaf blowers. It is possible to charge the batteries using solar power which will not only reduce pollution further by eschewing the use of electricity as the charging source, but can reduce costs further. There will be upfront costs for the solar charging equipment but modern solar panels that can generate enough wattage to charge batteries are not costly.  There may be concerns from environmentalists that the batteries can be a hazard to the environment when not disposed of correctly. This is indeed a genuine concern due to poisonous lithium inside the batteries. However, research has shown that overall, gas power is more harmful overall when all of this is taken into account. Furthermore, as battery technology improves, there may be a time when the batteries could be made entirely of non poisonous materials.  Given the points made above, it would be a sensible option to completely ban gas powered leaf blowers. There is no argument to support their continued usage and using battery as an alternative has so many advantages.

This change not only helped slow the spread of the virus but also transformed how work is done, with many employees and employers adapting quickly to the new normal.  During the remote work period, many employees took advantage of the flexibility to relocate outside of urban areas, seeking more spacious and affordable living arrangements. This shift meant that, for many workers, the traditional daily commute was eliminated, and work became integrated into their home environments. As a result, many companies now face the challenge of maintaining largely empty offices. In response, some employers are pushing for a return to the office several days a week, aiming to revitalize workplace culture, improve collaboration, and maximize the use of their real estate investments.  However, this demand places many workers in a difficult position. Employees who have grown accustomed to remote work now find it challenging to transition back to the old ways, especially those who relocated to suburbs or beyond. The balance between offering the benefits of in-person interaction and maintaining the flexibility that remote work provides has become a central point of debate. Some argue that hybrid models, combining office and remote work, might offer the best of both worlds.  In conclusion, the decision to require office returns or allow full remote schedules is complex. Large employers must weigh the advantages of in-person collaboration and office culture against the benefits of flexibility and employee satisfaction that remote work affords. Ultimately, a thoughtful, balanced approach tailored to the needs of both employers and employees will be essential in navigating the future of work.

This approach offers numerous advantages, including reductions in pollution, better utilization of urban infrastructure, and enhanced working conditions for employees. By enabling employees to work from home, the number of vehicles on the road decreases substantially, resulting in cleaner air and a smaller carbon footprint. Additionally, remote work alleviates pressure on public transportation and urban infrastructure. This is particularly advantageous for workers in roles that necessitate physical presence, as it improves access and facility availability where it is most needed.  From the employee perspective, remote work often translates to more flexible and comfortable working conditions, which can increase productivity and job satisfaction. Workers save time and money by avoiding daily commutes and can better balance professional and personal responsibilities. This flexibility can lead to higher retention rates and a healthier workforce overall.  However, a common concern is that widespread remote work could devalue inner-city real estate and disrupt urban economies. This challenge can be addressed through thoughtful urban planning. Cities and municipalities could engage in strategic rezoning to develop micro-communities — compact, mixed-use neighborhoods providing residents with essential amenities within walking or short driving distance. These micro-communities would promote high-density living similar to satellite towns or suburbs but on a smaller scale, revitalizing urban spaces and supporting local economies.  In conclusion, allowing fully remote work by default for eligible jobs is a forward-thinking strategy that benefits the environment, infrastructure, employees, and urban communities. With careful planning and innovative urban design, the potential drawbacks can be mitigated, making remote work a sustainable and desirable standard for large employers.

ai_draft_text: Should Cities Ban Gas-Powered Leaf Blowers?  The debate over whether cities should ban gas-powered leaf blowers to reduce noise and pollution has gained momentum in recent years. While concerns about environmental impact and noise pollution are valid, outright bans on gas-powered leaf blowers are not the ideal solution. Instead, cities should allow homeowners and landscapers the freedom to choose their equipment while implementing sensible regulations to manage usage.  One major advantage of gas-powered leaf blowers is their efficiency. Compared to electric models, gas-powered blowers generally provide more power, enabling users to complete landscaping tasks more quickly. This efficiency is especially important for professional landscapers who handle large properties or commercial spaces where extensive leaf removal is required. Electric leaf blowers, while quieter and cleaner, often lack the capacity and power needed to tackle these larger jobs effectively, making them less practical in many real-world scenarios.  Furthermore, rather than imposing outright bans, cities can adopt a balanced approach by governing the use of gas-powered equipment. This could include setting designated hours during which gas-powered leaf blowers are permitted to operate, restricting sales of the most polluting models, or encouraging the gradual transition to cleaner alternatives through incentives and education. Such regulatory measures allow cities to address noise and pollution concerns while preserving the flexibility for homeowners and landscapers to choose the equipment best suited to their needs.  In conclusion, banning gas-powered leaf blowers entirely overlooks the practical advantages they offer and the varied requirements of users. A more effective approach involves granting individuals the freedom to select their tools while cities implement reasonable guidelines to mitigate noise and environmental impacts. This balanced strategy ensures that the needs of both the community and the environment are thoughtfully considered.

outline_text: There have been a significant debate on how to deal with the growing burden of student debt. student loan forgiveness programs will not solve the issue.I think the gorvenment should focus on making education more affordable that is instead of giving the money to the students, the government should instead take the money direct to the schools and even it can make education more cheaper to reduce the burden of the increase in student loans.
ai_draft_text: The growing burden of student debt has sparked significant debate about the best approach for the federal government to take. While expanding student-loan forgiveness programs might seem like a direct solution, it ultimately does not address the root causes of the issue. Instead, the government should prioritize making education more affordable by targeting the cost of schooling itself rather than simply forgiving loans after they accumulate.  Student-loan forgiveness programs provide temporary relief for borrowers by canceling part or all of their debt. However, these programs often act as a band-aid rather than a cure. Forgiving loans does not prevent future students from accumulating similar or even larger debts, especially as tuition fees continue to rise. Moreover, loan forgiveness can be costly for taxpayers and may create an expectation that education costs will be mitigated after the fact, rather than encouraging systemic reform.  A more sustainable and equitable approach is for the government to focus on lowering the upfront cost of education. This could involve increasing direct funding to colleges and universities, helping institutions reduce tuition fees, and investing in programs that make higher education more accessible. By channeling funds straight to schools instead of to students, the government can work to control the rising costs that drive many students to take on substantial loans in the first place. Making education more affordable at the source would alleviate the financial burden on students and families, thereby reducing future debt accumulation.  In conclusion, expanding student-loan forgiveness programs fails to address the underlying problem of escalating education costs. The federal government should prioritize policies that make college more affordable by supporting schools directly and curbing tuition increases. Such measures promise a long-term solution that will help students avoid crushing debt rather than relying on forgiveness after the fact.

outline_text: Student loan forgiveness programs are effective but is not widely distributed. Partial forgiveness distributed more widely would be more effective and fairer. Discuss high income tax and compounded impact of student loan.  Discuss impact of inflation and cost of living on income. These factors cause 'brain drain': the most highly educated people move elsewhere and contribute to a different economy.
ai_draft_text: Student loan debt has become a pervasive challenge in the United States, affecting millions of borrowers and shaping economic prospects for a generation. While the federal government’s current student-loan forgiveness programs provide meaningful relief, their limited scope restricts their overall effectiveness. To address education debt more equitably and broadly, the government should consider partial loan forgiveness distributed more widely rather than focusing exclusively on full forgiveness for a select few.  One critical factor exacerbating the burden of student loans is the compounding nature of debt alongside high-income tax rates. Graduates often face the dual strain of repaying loans with accruing interest while surrendering a sizable portion of their income to taxes. This combination can significantly suppress disposable income and delay important life milestones such as homeownership and family formation. Moreover, the inflationary environment and rising cost of living further diminish the real value of earnings, making it increasingly difficult for borrowers to keep pace with loan repayments or build financial stability. The economic squeeze leaves many struggling to balance debt obligations with everyday expenses.  The consequences of these financial pressures extend beyond individual hardship and contribute to a broader societal challenge known as “brain drain.” Highly educated individuals, burdened by debt and discouraged by stagnant economic opportunities, may choose to relocate to regions or countries with more favorable economic conditions. This migration results in a loss of talent and innovation that could otherwise fuel domestic growth. By expanding student loan forgiveness programs to provide partial relief to a wider population of borrowers, the government can mitigate this brain drain by enhancing economic mobility and incentivizing graduates to contribute their skills to the national economy.  In conclusion, while targeted student-loan forgiveness programs offer benefits, a strategy prioritizing partial forgiveness for a broader base of borrowers would be more effective and fair. Addressing the compounded impact of student loan debt, high taxation, and inflation through widespread relief measures can reduce financial strain and help retain valuable human capital. Broadening forgiveness programs is a crucial step toward creating a more equitable and prosperous future for American workers.
final_text: Student loan debt has become a pervasive challenge in the United States, affecting millions of borrowers and shaping economic prospects for a generation. While the federal government’s current student-loan forgiveness programs provide meaningful relief, their limited scope restricts their overall effectiveness. To address education debt more equitably and broadly, the government should consider partial loan forgiveness distributed more widely rather than focusing exclusively on full forgiveness for a select few.  One critical factor exacerbating the burden of student loans is the compounding nature of debt alongside high-income tax rates. Graduates often face the dual strain of repaying loans with accruing interest while surrendering a sizable portion of their income to taxes. This combination can significantly suppress disposable income and delay important life milestones such as homeownership and family formation. Moreover, the inflationary environment and rising cost of living further diminish the real value of earnings, making it increasingly difficult for borrowers to keep pace with loan repayments or build financial stability. The economic squeeze leaves many struggling to balance debt obligations with everyday expenses.  The consequences of these financial pressures extend beyond individual hardship and contribute to a broader societal challenge known as “brain drain.” Highly educated individuals, burdened by debt and discouraged by stagnant economic opportunities, may choose to relocate to regions or countries with more favorable economic conditions. This migration results in a loss of talent and innovation that could otherwise fuel domestic growth. By expanding student loan forgiveness programs to provide partial relief to a wider population of borrowers, the government can mitigate this brain drain by enhancing economic mobility and incentivizing graduates to contribute their skills to the national economy.  In conclusion, while targeted student-loan forgiveness programs offer benefits, a strategy prioritizing partial forgiveness for a broader base of borrowers would be more effective and fair. Addressing the compounded impact of student loan debt, high taxation, and inflation through widespread relief measures can reduce financial strain and help retain valuable human capital. Broadening forgiveness programs is a crucial step toward creating a more equitable and prosperous future for American workers.

It is known that a happy workforce is a productive workforce. Hybrid working, some time spent in the office and some from home, increases employee happiness by giving them a greater degree of freedom and control over their working life. This both makes them happier during working hours, as things are more likely to be arranged to their preferences, and in turn also happier outside of working hours, on account of their job being more pleasurable for them as one that takes into account their preferences more. Workers can easily save several hours a day on the commute into an office, in many cases to perform tasks which can be done equally as well from the home environment. Similarly, with less workers in a central office, employers also benefit from reduced costs on things such as electricity for heating and lighting, in some cases even being able to downsize offices or sites needed due to a reduced presence of workers in those spaces.   This is not to deny various positives to a central office space in which the whole team is present. For a start, face to face interaction would obviously facilitate easier team working. It also helps with building stronger interpersonal relationships between workers, as they are more likely to talk and bond when sharing a physical space. This in turn further strengthens teamwork as employees are a closer knit unit.   In summary there are both positives and negatives to be considered. With people being wildly different in any large team a hybrid approach is surely the one that fits best for all, in allowing both employer and employee needs, and preferences, to be met, and not forcing strict routines where they are simply not necessary. Further flexibility within such a system allows nuance and different situations to be taken further into account.
