The in-office stalwarts do not know how to prioritize their work-life balance in the same way many of us have to. Furthermore, studies have shown that working from home reduces stress and that businesses that kept it as an option have shown less churn and turnover with time. It turns out people respond positively to being able to set their own schedule and determine how and when they get their work done. From the employer side, office space with exorbitant rents no longer has to be a worry if everyone is working from home. They've already paid their rent! And if you live at home, traffic and transportation are no longer an issue. You're already at work, so no need to sit in that traffic jam and lament the decisions you've made in life. It's for these many reasons that I think working from home is the way of the future when it comes to maintaining increased productivity, promoting a less stressful work environment, and prioritizing the overall wellbeing of ones employees. Being in the office has not proven to do any of these, and the proponents of the mandates know that. They just have rents to pay.

outline_text: Reasons for the Federal Government to prioritize ways of addressing student debt:  - Provide forgiveness for specific professions (i.e., teaching)  - Provide forgiveness for serving the country (i.e., military, forest service, etc)  - Create specific "government" schools that train for specific fields and result in no-to-low education debt  Reasons for the Federal Government to NOT broaden student-loan forgiveness:  - Increases national debt  - Allows for people to "game" the system  - Creates a dependency that people will expect  Reasons for the Federal Government to broaden student-loan forgiveness:  - Encourages more citizens to get an education  - Helps to raise marginalized people out of poverty  - Gives hope to those who need it the most
ai_draft_text: Student loan debt has become a pressing issue for many Americans, raising the question of whether the federal government should broaden student-loan forgiveness programs or prioritize other ways of addressing education debt. While expanding forgiveness has its merits, a balanced approach that includes targeted forgiveness and innovative educational reforms offers a more sustainable solution.  One effective way for the federal government to address student debt is by providing forgiveness programs tailored to specific professions. For example, forgiving loans for teachers or public servants incentivizes essential careers that contribute directly to society. Similarly, offering debt relief for those who serve the country in the military, forest service, or other government roles acknowledges their dedication and sacrifice. Another promising strategy is the creation of specialized government-run schools that focus on training for critical fields, allowing students to graduate with little or no debt. Such institutions would reduce the burden of education costs while aligning workforce needs with national priorities.  However, broadening student-loan forgiveness on a wide scale raises concerns. Increasing federal forgiveness programs could significantly add to the national debt, exacerbating fiscal challenges. There is also the risk that some individuals might exploit these programs, taking on loans with the intention of having them forgiven without a genuine commitment to their education or career. Moreover, broad forgiveness might promote a dependency mindset, where future students expect debt relief rather than financial responsibility.  Despite these drawbacks, expanding student-loan forgiveness has clear benefits. It can encourage more citizens to pursue higher education, opening paths to professional development and economic mobility. For marginalized communities, forgiveness programs can be a crucial tool in breaking cycles of poverty and creating opportunities previously out of reach. Most importantly, student-loan forgiveness offers hope and relief to millions burdened by debt, fostering a fairer and more accessible education system.  In conclusion, while broad student-loan forgiveness has potential pitfalls, prioritizing targeted forgiveness for specific professions and innovative educational solutions strikes a balance. This approach not only mitigates the risks associated with broad forgiveness but also addresses education debt in a way that benefits individuals and society as a whole.

outline_text: Few would argue the benefits of higher education to the economy, however the question of how to address the economic burden of this education has historically proven somewhat more contentious.   On the one hand, loan forgiveness expands access to education and can stimulate economic growth through increased spending. On other hand, there are contrasting concerns that this forgiveness risks financial strain, and reduces the need for identifying other, more economically sustainable, methods for addressing the issue of mounting student debt.
human_draft_text: The disparity between contrasting, and often incompatible, views on student debt is only compounding by increasing politicisation of the challenges of funding higher education access as they are integrated into broader themes of political discourse. The left will argue that access to this education is an essential part of developing a fair, equal, and egalitarian society with equal opportunities for all, where's the right will argue education being something that is earned not given; being neither a right or a requirement of an economically successful country.   The only question that really needs answering of course is "what maximises value teconomy?". If higher education is rarefied the likely downstream consequence would shortages of skills in critical technical areas as well as shortages in other highly skilled sectors such as healthcare and pharmaceuticals. This would lead to an increasing reliance on immigration to bridge the skills gap, whilst risking the very real scenario where the country begins to lag behind others in terms of innovation which ultimately strains local businesses ability to maintain a competitive advantage in the face of foreign imports of both products and labour.

human_draft_text: A very common debate over the last five years has been whether large employers should require workers to return to the office several days a week, or allow fully remote schedules by default. Since CoVid-19 hit in 2020, the work landscape has changed significantly.   The lockdown of most countries meant that a significant amount of roles - especially white-collar roles - were done remotely for the duration. Following this, many workers decided to move further out of cities (reducing their costs), and realised that it was possible to have a better work/life balance.  There are confliction opinions on whether there should be fully remote schedules or requirements to work from office per week. For sure, there is a better work/life balance usually for those who are able to work from home - something that the younger generation of worker definitely values; and this can be a way of enticing the top-performing younger recruits. In fact, with the correct work ethic, home workers can actually do more than their allotted hours due to eating lunch at desks/shorter breaks, and not having to rush to catch public transport. As well as this, there is a positive environmental consideration with working from home - less traffic on the roads, less mileage and congestion and public transport is less crowded. A larger company could move to 'hot desking' also downsize offices slightly, a financial positive.  As with any consideration, there are negatives too. A major downside is the lack of camaraderie within a remote office - which could actually lead to retention issues and higher turnover, as there is no reason to worry about 'jumping ship' and leaving for slightly better conditions. Valuable knowledge is also not as easily transferable in a remote office. Although most firms have software for electronic communication, it is still not as easy as talking to a more knowledgeable colleague in the office. In terms of office space, many companies have long leases (or own offices) which are difficult to get rid of and these could be sitting empty. Furthermore - maybe not a direct consideration for larger companies - but the wider economy can, and does suffer, as workers aren't buying lunch/coffee etc.  Overall, it's a very nuanced discussion - with pros and cons - but it does seem like a hybrid system, with a lot of flexibility when and how to work from home as needed, may be the best scenario for all parties.

Every company should make the decision about in person vs. remote work based on what is best for their profit and productivity.  This decision should be free of government interference as well as the stagnation of old habit thinking.  Every company should be left to plan for their long term viability and profit margins while considering new possibilities.  Employee satisfaction is not their number one goal, nor should it be ignored.  Happiness and more control over work/life balance for employees should be one consideration, if all else is equal. It's also highly likely that all things will not be equal.  Different workspaces have different needs for the type of work, culture, and output required to be successful. However, there will inevitably by some companies who find that their remote workers are either just as or more productive overall when working from home. ai_draft_text: In recent years, the debate over whether large employers should require workers to return to the office several days a week or allow fully remote schedules by default has gained significant attention. While remote work offers certain conveniences, it is crucial for companies to adopt a hybrid work environment that balances in-office presence with remote flexibility. Requiring employees to come to the office several days a week ensures stronger team connections, preserves company culture, and enhances overall productivity.  One of the primary benefits of a hybrid work model is that it fosters meaningful team interactions. In-person collaboration allows employees to build rapport and trust, which are difficult to replicate through virtual meetings alone. This is especially important for new hires, who rely on one-on-one interactions with colleagues to fully understand a company’s values and integrate smoothly into the workplace. By sharing physical workspace several days a week, employees can participate in spontaneous conversations and informal mentoring that enrich the work experience and strengthen relationships.  Moreover, working from the office tends to boost productivity. While some employees thrive in remote settings, others are easily distracted at home by household responsibilities or a lack of dedicated workspace. The structured environment of an office helps minimize these distractions and encourages focus. Additionally, being physically present can facilitate quicker problem-solving and more efficient communication, which boosts overall work performance.  Finally, having employees return to the office reinforces a sense of accountability and maintains a clear corporate structure. The presence of supervisors and team leaders in the office creates a professional atmosphere where expectations are transparent and responsibilities are enforced. This structure is essential for effective management, ensuring that projects stay on track and company goals are met.  In conclusion, although fully remote work has its advantages, large employers should require workers to return to the office several days a week. A hybrid model promotes stronger team connections, preserves company culture, enhances productivity, and upholds corporate accountability—factors that are vital for long-term organizational success.

Whilst the adjustment was tricky for some, others thrived under this new approach. Now that life has returned to some semblance of normal, home working has remained in a vast number of organisations.  Pros of returning: - Increased office culture and teamwork - Additional oversight over employees by managers  Cons of returning - Increased difficulty for workers with a long commute or who require the flexibility of home working  - Additional business costs for larger office space and overheads
human_draft_text: During the Covid-19 pandemic, significant numbers of office-based workers were forced to work from home, often for the first time. Whilst the adjustment was tricky for some, others thrived under this new approach. Now that life has returned to some semblance of normal, home working has remained in a vast number of organisations. Many companies across the private and public sector are assessing whether to require workers to return to the office for several days a week, or to allow fully remote schedules by default.   On the one hand, requiring employees to return to the office would have a number of benefits. Links between teams are often strengthened when working in close proximity, with social bonds growing more easily. Team members and their managers can often find it easier to collaborate and problem solve on a face to face basis, as opposed to over the phone or email. Companies also often prefer to have an office culture, which can only be built if workers are present on site. Additionally, managers and senior leaders are able to have more oversight over employees and their productivity when all in one place.   On the other hand, there are a number of positives for both workers and employers around remote working. Colleagues can work more flexibly, balancing home and work life more easily, when they do not need to commute to the office. Having a mostly remote workforce can enable companies to downsize their office space and avoid some of the more costly overheads associated with having workers on-site. It has also allowed organisations to recruit staff who - due to location - would not have traditionally applied for such roles if the requirement was to regularly attend the office, giving access to a much wider talent pool.   In conclusion, it does not appear that there is one correct approach for everyone. There are risks and benefits associated with either option, and each company has to assess it's needs and priorities in order to make the most appropriate decision. It may be that a more hybrid option is adopted, with employees attending the office one or two days a week, to truly take advantage of both styles of working.

Can be home to provide care for family when workload allows. Employers: Less need for office space. Can hire employees from anywhere and not just locally. Gives them a competitive hiring advantage over businesses that require in office working full time.
ai_draft_text: In recent years, the debate over whether large employers should require workers to return to the office several days a week or allow fully remote schedules by default has gained considerable attention. While in-person collaboration has its merits, the advantages of working from home present a strong case for making remote work the default option for many employees. Both workers and employers stand to benefit significantly from flexible, home-based work arrangements.  For employees, working from home eliminates the daily commute, which often consumes valuable time and energy. Avoiding long drives or crowded public transit not only saves money on fuel and public transportation fares but also reduces wear and tear on personal vehicles, lowering maintenance costs. The time once spent commuting can instead be devoted to personal activities, rest, or family commitments, greatly improving work-life balance. Moreover, remote work allows employees to be physically present at home to provide care for family members when their workload permits, fostering a supportive environment that can enhance overall well-being and job satisfaction.  Employers, too, gain numerous advantages from allowing remote work by default. First and foremost, businesses can reduce expenses incurred by maintaining large office spaces, including rent, utilities, and maintenance costs. Additionally, remote work broadens the talent pool considerably, as companies are no longer restricted to hiring candidates from their local area. This geographic flexibility enables firms to recruit highly skilled employees regardless of location, increasing the quality and diversity of their workforce. Furthermore, offering remote work options grants employers a competitive edge in the hiring market. Many prospective employees now prioritize flexibility, and companies that embrace remote work can attract and retain top talent more effectively than those insisting on full-time office presence.  In conclusion, the benefits of remote work for both employees and employers make a compelling argument for large employers to adopt fully remote schedules by default. Saving time and money, improving work-life balance, reducing overhead costs, and expanding recruitment opportunities highlight how remote work can create a more productive and satisfied workforce while enhancing business success.

ai_draft_text: In many cities, the debate over whether to ban gas-powered leaf blowers has gained significant attention. Personally, I believe that cities should ban these machines to reduce both noise and air pollution, ultimately promoting healthier and more sustainable communities.  Firstly, gas-powered leaf blowers contribute substantially to air pollution. These devices emit harmful pollutants, including carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and volatile organic compounds, which not only degrade air quality but also lead to serious health problems such as respiratory issues and cardiovascular diseases. By banning gas-powered leaf blowers, cities can significantly cut down on these emissions, creating a cleaner and safer environment for residents.  In addition to air pollution, noise pollution caused by gas-powered leaf blowers is a considerable concern. The loud noise produced by these machines can disrupt daily life, disturb neighbors, and contribute to stress and anxiety. Reducing the use of gas-powered blowers will help lower overall noise levels in neighborhoods, fostering a more peaceful and comfortable living environment.  Moreover, banning gas-powered leaf blowers can contribute positively to the global fight against climate change. These machines rely on fossil fuels that release carbon dioxide, a major greenhouse gas, into the atmosphere. By eliminating gas-powered blowers and encouraging the use of electric or manual alternatives, cities can reduce their carbon footprint and support broader climate goals.  Opponents may argue that banning gas-powered leaf blowers infringes on personal freedom and imposes financial burdens on homeowners and landscapers who must replace their equipment. While there is some validity to this concern, it is important to consider the larger picture. The health benefits, noise reduction, and environmental gains far outweigh the short-term inconveniences and costs. Cities must prioritize the well-being of their communities and the environment for the greater good.  In conclusion, banning gas-powered leaf blowers is a necessary step for cities aiming to reduce air and noise pollution and combat climate change. While challenges exist, the long-term advantages make such a ban a positive and responsible choice.

Personally, I believe that cities should implement such bans to reduce both noise and air pollution, which would benefit public health and the environment.  One of the primary reasons I support banning gas-powered leaf blowers is to reduce air pollution. These machines emit a considerable amount of harmful pollutants, including carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and volatile organic compounds. These emissions not only degrade air quality but also contribute to respiratory problems such as asthma and other chronic conditions. By eliminating gas-powered blowers, cities can improve the overall health of their residents and reduce the strain on healthcare systems.  Additionally, noise pollution caused by gas-powered leaf blowers is a substantial concern. The loud, constant noise can disrupt the peace of neighborhoods, negatively impacting mental well-being and productivity. Prolonged exposure to such noise can lead to increased stress levels, hearing loss, and sleep disturbances. Banning these noisy machines would create a quieter, more pleasant environment for everyone.  Moreover, a ban on gas-powered leaf blowers aligns with broader efforts to combat climate change. These devices contribute to greenhouse gas emissions that accelerate global warming, a challenge that demands collective action. Transitioning to electric or manual alternatives reduces carbon footprints and promotes sustainable urban living.  Opponents might argue that banning gas-powered leaf blowers infringes on personal freedom and that replacing equipment can be costly for homeowners and landscapers. However, when considering the bigger picture, the benefits of cleaner air, reduced noise pollution, and climate change mitigation significantly outweigh the drawbacks. Cities have a responsibility to prioritize public health and environmental sustainability over convenience.  In conclusion, banning gas-powered leaf blowers is a necessary step toward healthier, quieter, and more sustainable communities. The positive outcomes from such policies will far surpass the temporary inconveniences faced by individuals, making the decision both justified and important.

ai_draft_text: Student loan debt in the United States has reached staggering levels, with outstanding student loans totaling approximately $1.6 trillion. This debt is held by borrowers across various age groups, with a significant portion owed by individuals under 40, but a growing number of older Americans are also carrying student loan balances. On average, borrowers pay around $400 per month to service their student loans, a financial burden that can inhibit their ability to save, invest, or participate fully in the economy. Additionally, default rates on these loans remain concerning, with about 10% of borrowers defaulting within the first few years of repayment.  The economic impact of alleviating student loan indebtedness could be profound. If borrowers were relieved from or had reduced monthly payments, they might increase spending on goods and services, thereby stimulating economic growth. Increased consumer spending could benefit businesses, create jobs, and lead to higher tax revenues, which partially offset the initial cost of loan relief programs.  However, student loan forgiveness is not the only path to addressing this issue. Alternative strategies include income-driven repayment plans that adjust payments based on borrowers’ ability to pay, expanding access to loan refinancing at lower interest rates, and increasing funding for grants and scholarships to reduce the need for loans in the first place. These alternatives may offer more sustainable, targeted approaches to reducing borrower stress without the broad fiscal impact of wholesale debt cancellation.  From a fiscal perspective, broad student loan forgiveness would impose significant costs on the federal government, potentially adding hundreds of billions to the national debt. This could necessitate increased taxes or reduced spending in other critical areas. Conversely, alternative solutions such as refinancing or income-driven repayment plans could be less costly in the short term and promote responsible lending practices.  In conclusion, while broadening student loan forgiveness programs offers immediate relief for many borrowers, prioritizing alternative ways to address education debt may present a more balanced approach. These methods can provide sustainable economic benefits without imposing excessive financial burdens on the federal government, ensuring that education remains accessible and affordable for future generations.

ai_draft_text: In recent years, the presence of smartphones in schools has become a topic of considerable debate. While some advocate for limited use of these devices for learning and emergencies, I firmly believe that public schools should ban smartphones for all pupils during the school day. The primary reason for this stance is that mobile phones serve as a constant distraction, preventing students from fully engaging in their lessons and focusing on their education.  Many pupils are persistently tempted to sneak a glance at their phones, whether in class, in the restroom, or while transitioning between lessons. This behavior interrupts their concentration and detracts from the educational environment that schools strive to maintain. The main purpose of attending school is to learn, and smartphones often divert attention away from this goal. Instead of fostering productive learning habits, mobile devices can encourage multitasking and reduce comprehension of the material being taught.  In cases where students need to contact their parents, such as to inform them about a cancelled match or change in transportation plans, there should be alternative communication methods available. Schools can provide access to a dedicated school mobile phone or a fixed-line phone, ensuring that students can reach out in emergencies without needing to carry their personal smartphones. Additionally, if students require devices for independent learning activities, the school should supply a set of tablets or iPads specifically for educational purposes. This eliminates the need for pupils to rely on their own mobile devices during school hours.  Moreover, banning smartphones during the day allows pupils to ‘detox’ from constant screen time and digital distractions. It also promotes better social interaction and communication skills, which are often undermined when students focus more on their phones than on face-to-face conversations. Groups of young people frequently appear isolated from one another despite being physically together, due to their engagement with phones. Removing these devices from the school environment encourages more meaningful connections among peers.  In conclusion, while smartphones may have their benefits, the distractions they cause in a school setting outweigh these advantages. Banning smartphones during the school day helps maintain a focused learning atmosphere, supports alternative communication methods, and enhances students’ social skills. Public schools should therefore implement a complete ban on smartphones for all pupils during school hours.
final_text: In today’s increasingly digital world, the presence of smartphones in schools has become a controversial topic. While some argue for limited use of phones during the school day to aid learning and for emergencies, I firmly believe that public schools should ban smartphones for all pupils. The primary reason for this is that mobile phones serve as a constant distraction, preventing students from fully engaging in their lessons.  Many pupils are tempted to sneak a look at their phones throughout the day, whether during class, between lessons, or even in the restroom. This behavior diverts their attention away from the main purpose of being at school: to learn. The temptation to check messages, social media, or play games can reduce concentration and negatively impact academic performance. A smartphone ban would help ensure that students remain focused and present in the classroom.  In situations where pupils need to contact their parents, such as when a match is cancelled and transportation arrangements need to be changed, schools can provide alternatives. A designated school mobile phone or access to a fixed-line phone should be available to students for such emergencies. This approach addresses communication needs without compromising the learning environment. Furthermore, for educational purposes that require the use of technology, schools should provide communal devices like iPads. These can be carefully monitored and used exclusively for learning activities, eliminating the necessity for students to rely on their personal smartphones.  An important additional benefit of banning smartphones during the school day is that it allows students to “detox” from constant digital stimulation. This break from screens encourages more face-to-face interaction, helping to improve communication skills. It is all too common nowadays to see groups of young people absorbed in their phones rather than engaging with each other directly.  In conclusion, schools should ban smartphones during the school day to reduce distractions, maintain focus on learning, and promote better interpersonal skills among pupils. This policy supports a healthier, more productive educational environment for all students.

human_draft_text: Student Loan debt in America is a problem that impacts many people in the younger generations Gen Z, X and Y today.  These generations grew up in a time when the idea was widely supported that if you do well in school and make it through college, the rewards in return will secure a great job and foundation of your success.  However, in 2025 that path leads to all but uncertainty and is not the surefire equation it once was.   To achieve this, millions of young people secured student loans before entering college to further reach that promise of a secure future and job in the end, with relatively ease of paying it back.  Unfortunately today, we live in a nation where it is more expensive for your young people to take out student loans, than it is to buy a house.  There is over a trillion dollars in federal loan debt that needs repayed with the debt doubling in the last two decades.  The government needs to step in and broaden loan forgiveness programs.   Many people struggle with loan repayments today and are not able to move forward with their lives as they are hampered by this debt.   The financial institutions and schools who sold these loans also need regulation - student loan interest rate should be capped at a much lower percent.  These institutions also should be regulated to give out loans on professions where there is a reasonable chance an individual can secure a job and in turn repay.  These institutions and especially for profit colleges are almost predatory, similar to what ocurred during the housing and financial crisis.  It makes no sense to issue a 100,000 dollar loan to someone who is majoring in anthropology or a useless field. If there were stipulations that pushed people into programs like STEM, education, medical, social work, etc where there is a need for workers in these fields that would also help the shortage.  The state and federal government should implement more policies, where if you have an education degree and work in our city your loans are forgiven, of if you become a police officer, or a nurse etc.  We need our young people to have promising futures and we need more people in more in demand fields. Releasing the debt burden is better for all.   The wages today have not kept up with costs of housing, college, and many other things that were very easy to afford for previous generations.    We need to urge our elected leaders and government to address this crisis and issue by implementing these programs, the future of our younger generations and the strength of our economy depends on it.

Gas-powered leaf blowers produce excessive noise characterized by high volume and low-frequency sounds that carry far beyond the immediate area. Chronic exposure to such noise pollution can lead to increased stress, anxiety, and other mental health problems among residents. Moreover, the burden disproportionately falls on landscapers who are exposed to these loud machines for extended periods, putting their hearing and well-being at risk.  In addition to noise, gas-powered leaf blowers emit harmful pollutants, including carbon monoxide and particulate matter that degrade air quality. They release greenhouse gases, contributing to climate change through CO2 emissions. These environmental hazards are particularly troubling given the availability of cleaner options.  Fortunately, viable alternatives exist. Electric leaf blowers have become increasingly affordable, quieter, and more efficient, offering a practical replacement for gas-powered models. Additionally, manual tools like rakes provide an eco-friendly option, especially in smaller spaces. The transition to these alternatives is both feasible and beneficial.  Several cities have already banned gas-powered leaf blowers or imposed restrictions, demonstrating that regulation is workable with appropriate enforcement strategies. Support programs can help landscapers and homeowners switch to electric models, mitigating economic impacts.  Opponents argue that electric blowers lack the power of gas engines, that bans hurt small landscaping businesses, or that such regulations represent government overreach. However, ongoing technological improvements address power concerns, support initiatives can aid small businesses, and the regulation is justified by public health and environmental protection.  In conclusion, cities should enact ordinances banning gas-powered leaf blowers with phased implementation plans. Protecting community health, preserving tranquility, and reducing pollution make such measures essential steps toward sustainable urban living.

outline_text: I do not believe employers should force workers to return to the office, and should instead opt to allow for fully remote work environments. Reasons for my beliefs include: more flexibility within the work day; this allows for workers to not only attend to their work, but also that of their household, when applicable. Additionally, it cuts down on costs for transportation; with the increase in gas prices and cost of vehicle maintenance, working a full time job within a reasonable distance can sometimes not be possible. Remote work allows for that work to be completed anywhere, without the extra cost of gas and vehicle maintenance. I also think that it leads to better productivity and higher worker outcomes and overall improvement of work culture.   Forcing people to return to the office is arcane and seems to just be an overreach of power and inflexibility. I think forcing people to return to the office also feels very parental and dictatorial. It feels like employers may not treat staff like adults, but instead as cogs in a working machine, which I also think is strange.

I believe there are many benefits to working in a fully remote set up. The increase in flexibility being one; a diminishing of automotive expenses, commute time and gas expensing; and the overall improvement of worker outcomes and productivity, as a whole.   Working professionals are busy and their lives don't always revolve around work. In fact, many people have household priorities, like childcare, supporting a sick loved one, or just tending to the house and other domestic responsibilities. Those responsibilities shouldn't always wait until work is done, but in fact that coexist within the workplace. With remote work, professionals can complete their work, and also attend to household duties and tasks without either of them interfering with the other. This leads to better family dynamics and mental health for the entire family unit.   In addition, with the economically uncertain climate, gas prices and the cost of vehicle maintenance continues to go up. Commuting to work can be an unnecessary expense that remote work would eliminate. By not having to commute into work, professionals can instead use those saved funds on essential things that they need for their households, and they would also be able to save the overall stress and aggravation from commuting against busy traffic.   Finally, I think that a remote set-up leads to an improved outcome in productivity. While working from home, professionals are less likely to be interrupted by a coworker, or ringing phone, or general office chatter, and can instead really focus on their work in a comfortable environment. With improved focus, they can get their work done more efficiently.

Central argument: Younger generations such as Gen Z and Millennials were promised that going to college and getting a degree was a safe and ideal path for securing a job and making a living. Soaring housing costs, cost of living, and the disruption of the workforce by AI have made it so that getting a college degree is not a guarantee of a job and a comfortable living. These generations were falsely promised this by older generations and they deserve assistance through student loan forgiveness.   Supporting Arguments: The high cost of student loan monthly payments makes it hard to pay bills in a constantly more expensive society.   Conclusion: Student loands should be forgivven.
ai_draft_text: The escalating burden of student-loan debt in the United States has reached an alarming level, posing a serious threat to the financial stability and well-being of millions of Americans. Each year, more graduates find themselves trapped under the weight of loans that seem to grow faster than their ability to repay them. This crisis demands urgent attention, with the federal government facing a critical choice: to broaden student-loan forgiveness programs or to prioritize other solutions. Given the circumstances, expanding loan forgiveness is not only justified but necessary.  Younger generations, specifically Millennials and Gen Z, were raised with the common belief that attending college and earning a degree was the safest and most reliable pathway to gainful employment and a comfortable life. Unfortunately, this expectation has proven increasingly unreliable. Skyrocketing housing prices, rising costs of living, and rapid changes in the labor market owing to technological advances like artificial intelligence have severely disrupted job prospects. A college degree no longer guarantees the stable employment or economic security once promised. These younger Americans were encouraged to invest heavily in higher education under false pretenses, leaving them burdened with debt and limited prospects. It is fair and just for society to offer them relief through expanded student-loan forgiveness programs.  Furthermore, the crushing monthly payments required to manage student loans severely restrict financial flexibility. When coupled with rising expenses for essentials such as rent, healthcare, and food, these payments strain household budgets and reduce the ability of young adults to save, invest, or contribute to the economy. Forgiving student loans would alleviate this pressure, enabling borrowers to rebuild their financial lives and stimulate broader economic growth.  In conclusion, the federal government should broaden student-loan forgiveness programs. Doing so would address a broken promise, relieve the financial hardships facing younger generations, and promote a healthier economy. Student-loan forgiveness is not merely a financial policy—it is a necessary step toward fairness and economic justice.
final_text: The rising burden of student-loan debt in the United States has become an uncontrollable crisis affecting millions of Americans. With outstanding student debt surpassing $1.7 trillion, many borrowers struggle to keep up with monthly payments while managing other living expenses. This growing financial strain calls for urgent federal intervention to alleviate the burden on current and future graduates.  Younger generations, particularly Millennials and Gen Z, were led to believe that obtaining a college degree guaranteed a stable job and a comfortable life. This narrative, largely perpetuated by older generations, positioned higher education as a safe investment for economic security. However, soaring housing costs, increasing living expenses, and ongoing disruptions in the labor market caused by automation and artificial intelligence have shattered this promise. Today, many degree holders face underemployment or unemployment, making it difficult to repay student loans. This disconnect between expectation and reality highlights the need to reconsider how society supports those burdened by education debt.  Moreover, the high monthly payments required for student loans often consume a significant portion of borrowers’ income, leaving little room for necessities such as rent, healthcare, and food. In an economy where the cost of living continues to rise, the weight of student debt exacerbates financial insecurity and stifles economic mobility. Young families often need both partners to work in order to survive, which adds even more additional costs such as childcare into the equation. Poor social services, expensive healthcare costs, and insufficient opportunities for maternity and paternity leave compared to other countries all contribute to younger generations' struggles to make ends meet.   Forgiving student loans would provide immediate relief, allowing individuals to redirect their resources towards building wealth, purchasing homes, or investing in their futures.  In conclusion, broadening student-loan forgiveness programs is a necessary step to address the unjust financial challenges confronting younger generations. By acknowledging the broken promises linked to higher education and the harsh economic realities of modern life, the federal government can foster greater equity and economic stability. Rather than prioritizing alternative solutions that may take years to yield results, immediate loan forgiveness offers a direct and impactful means of supporting millions of Americans in distress.

ai_draft_text: The idea of bringing back extinct species like woolly mammoths through genetic engineering is both fascinating and controversial. While the prospect of reviving creatures that have long vanished from the Earth captures the imagination, I believe we should refrain from doing so. Extinction, after all, is a natural boundary that has been shaped over millions of years, and intervening in this process could lead to unintended consequences.  Firstly, species become extinct for a reason. In the case of the woolly mammoth, a combination of climate change and human activity contributed to their disappearance thousands of years ago. These factors disrupted their habitat and food sources, ultimately leading to their extinction. Attempting to bring back such species ignores the original causes of extinction and assumes that the same conditions that led to their downfall can somehow be reversed or controlled.  Moreover, extinction is a natural part of the evolutionary process. It allows ecosystems to evolve and adapt, giving rise to new species and balanced food chains. Reintroducing extinct species into a modern environment could disrupt existing ecosystems. Since species like woolly mammoths have been absent for so long, they no longer fit neatly within today’s ecological networks. Their presence could upset the balance of predator-prey relationships, compete with current species for resources, and even introduce unforeseen diseases.  Finally, the potential harms of resurrecting extinct animals may outweigh the benefits. Genetic engineering is still a developing field, and the ethical considerations surrounding the welfare of these recreated creatures are complex. Additionally, resources spent on de-extinction efforts might be better directed toward conserving endangered species and protecting current biodiversity.  In conclusion, although the allure of reviving extinct species is understandable, we should respect extinction as a natural boundary. The reasons behind a species’ disappearance, the risks to existing ecosystems, and ethical concerns suggest that we ought to focus our efforts on preserving the natural world as it is rather than trying to undo the past.

Attempting to bring back such species ignores the original causes of extinction and assumes that the same conditions that led to their downfall can somehow be reversed or controlled. ai_draft_text: Advancements in genetic technology have brought us to the threshold of a new era where parents may soon have the ability to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent diseases. This process, known as genetic modification or gene editing, involves altering the DNA of an embryo to eliminate hereditary illnesses or predispositions to certain health conditions. While this scientific breakthrough offers tremendous promise, it also raises complex ethical and social questions that must be carefully considered.  One of the primary benefits of allowing parents to genetically modify their children is the potential to ensure healthier offspring. By removing genes linked to serious diseases such as cystic fibrosis, Huntington’s disease, or certain cancers, parents can spare their children from lifelong suffering and reduce medical costs. Additionally, this could alleviate parental anxiety about inherited conditions. On a larger scale, widespread use of gene editing could lead to a generally healthier population with a lower burden on healthcare systems, potentially increasing life expectancy and quality of life.  However, the practice of genetic modification is not without significant drawbacks. A major concern is the potential loss of natural genetic diversity, which plays an essential role in human adaptability and resilience to evolving diseases. Unforeseen genetic consequences could also emerge, as our understanding of the genome remains incomplete. Moral and religious objections often arise from the belief that genetic editing constitutes “playing God,” interfering with the natural course of human life. Furthermore, the technology may exacerbate existing socioeconomic inequalities, as only wealthy families might afford such procedures, leading to a genetic “class divide.”  In conclusion, while the ability to genetically edit unborn children to prevent diseases holds remarkable potential for improving human health, it also presents ethical dilemmas and risks that cannot be ignored. A cautious approach, involving thorough regulation and public discourse, is necessary to balance the benefits of reducing suffering with the imperative to preserve human diversity and social equity. Ultimately, society must carefully weigh the promise of genetic editing against the value of natural human variation and moral considerations.

ai_draft_text: The rising burden of student loan debt is a defining challenge for millions of Americans today. Education remains a vital pathway to personal advancement and societal progress, yet the soaring costs threaten to exclude many from accessing higher education. In addressing this issue, while expanding student-loan forgiveness programs might offer immediate relief, it falls short as a lasting solution. To truly ensure universal access to education, the federal government must focus on making higher education more affordable or even free.  The student debt crisis is undeniable, with nearly half of all college graduates carrying significant loan balances. These debts influence life decisions, from delaying home ownership to forgoing starting a family, effectively stalling generations’ economic growth. Education itself is crucial—not only for individual success but also as a driver of innovation and a competitive workforce. Thus, the stakes are high for governments and society to find sustainable solutions that do more than simply erase debt after it has accumulated. Forgiveness initiatives typically provide debt relief for borrowers after years of repayment or through partial cancellation. However, these programs do not address the underlying issue of why college costs continue to spiral upwards. Without tackling the root causes, such forgiveness efforts risk recurring debt crises as new students continue to incur high expenses.  The more effective approach centers on reducing the cost of higher education itself. Countries like Australia have implemented systems that limit upfront costs for students through income-contingent loan repayment models and increased public investment in universities. By focusing on affordability from the start, the government can prevent overwhelming debt and improve access for all socioeconomic groups. Making higher education cheap or free is not merely an idealistic vision but a practical necessity to break the cycle of debt and broaden opportunities for all Americans. True progress depends on reimagining the cost structure of higher education itself to ensure it is accessible and affordable. Only then can higher education fulfill its promise as a universal ladder to opportunity.

outline_text: In an age where screens dominate large portions of our days both as adults and children, banning smartphone use in K-12 classrooms has the potential to improve learning outcomes, reduce distraction, increase focus time, and foster deeper social interactions in crucial developmental years. ai_draft_text: In today’s digital age, smartphones have become an integral part of daily life for people of all ages, including children. While these devices offer numerous benefits, their presence in K-12 classrooms often undermines the educational environment. Banning smartphones during the school day has the potential to significantly improve learning outcomes, reduce distractions, increase students’ focus, and foster deeper social interactions during crucial developmental years.  One of the most compelling reasons to prohibit smartphones in schools is the positive impact on learning outcomes. Several studies have highlighted that schools implementing phone bans have seen marked improvements in student performance. For example, a study conducted in the United Kingdom found that test scores increased by as much as 6.4% in schools that banned mobile phones, indicating that removing these devices can lead to better academic achievement. By removing the temptation to check messages or browse social media, students can devote more cognitive resources to understanding and retaining lessons.  Smartphones are notorious for creating distractions, and numerous real-world classroom examples illustrate this. Teachers frequently report that students diverted by their phones miss important instructions or fall behind in class discussions. In some cases, educators have shared stories of students sneaking glances at their screens during exams, compromising their focus and academic integrity. Eliminating smartphones removes this temptation and helps create a more conducive learning space.  Moreover, banning smartphones can increase students’ attention spans and focus time. Anecdotal evidence from teachers suggests that without the pull of smartphones, students engage more deeply with materials and participate more actively in lessons. This heightened focus is crucial in fostering critical thinking skills and encouraging sustained mental effort.  Finally, restricting smartphone use helps foster richer social interactions during school hours. Without the barrier of screens, students are more likely to communicate face-to-face, building essential interpersonal skills. For instance, schools that have implemented phone bans report improved peer relationships and increased involvement in group activities, which contribute positively to social development.  In summary, banning smartphones during the school day offers numerous benefits, including enhanced learning outcomes, reduced distractions, greater focus, and stronger social connections. As classrooms strive to prepare students for a complex world, minimizing smartphone use during school hours is a practical step toward creating an environment where learning and personal growth can flourish.

outline_text: Introduction My Argument: We should leave extinction as a natural boundary, barring any environmental or otherwise mutually beneficial positive. Otherwise, just bringing back for curiosity sake without considering repercussions Argument for reasons - cool, a look at previous times and world, learning opportunities, could benefit ecosystem in some way Argument against reasons - potentially dangerous, replicating animals across time periods without the same conditions, need for extinct animals has likely evolved Conclusion - while tempting, don’t do it.
ai_draft_text: The idea of bringing back extinct species like woolly mammoths through genetic engineering has captured the imagination of many. While the prospect is undeniably fascinating, I firmly believe that we should leave extinction as a natural boundary—except in cases where reviving a species offers clear environmental or mutual benefits. Reviving extinct animals purely out of curiosity, without carefully considering the potential repercussions, is a gamble we should avoid.  On one hand, resurrecting extinct species could provide unique opportunities to observe creatures that once roamed the Earth, offering valuable insights into past ecosystems and evolutionary processes. Woolly mammoths, for example, are emblematic of the Ice Age world and studying them firsthand could potentially deepen our understanding of climate change and ecological balance. Additionally, in some cases, bringing back certain species might help restore ecosystems that have lost key players, possibly improving biodiversity and environmental health.  However, the argument against reviving extinct animals is more compelling. Reintroducing species into a world vastly different from the one they originally inhabited carries significant risks. Environmental conditions, predator-prey relationships, and available resources have all evolved since these animals disappeared. The presence of such creatures might upset existing ecological balances, introduce unforeseen diseases, or cause other environmental problems. Moreover, the reasons for their extinction often remain relevant; bringing them back without addressing underlying issues may be futile or even harmful. Ethically, we must question whether humans have the right to manipulate nature in this way simply for curiosity or novelty.  In conclusion, although the idea of resurrecting woolly mammoths and other extinct species is tempting, it is not a venture to be taken lightly. Without clear, mutual benefits and thorough consideration of ecological impacts, we should respect extinction as a natural boundary and refrain from crossing it. The focus should instead be on preserving the species that are currently endangered and maintaining the delicate balance of today's ecosystems.

outline_text: - General topic approach  - Educational loan importance  - Negative implications  - Cost of higher education  -Increase in economic growth  -General view of student loan benefit  - Increase education funding reforms  - Indulgent of other agencies, organizations and NGO's
ai_draft_text: Student loan debt has become a pressing issue in the United States, sparking debates about the best ways to alleviate the financial burden on millions of borrowers. As education costs continue to rise, many have called for the federal government to broaden student-loan forgiveness programs. However, it is crucial to weigh this approach against other strategies that might more effectively address the root causes of education debt and foster long-term economic benefits.  Student loans are essential for many individuals seeking higher education, providing access to opportunities that might otherwise be unattainable. A college degree often leads to better job prospects and higher lifetime earnings, underscoring the importance of financing options. Nevertheless, the negative implications of accumulating substantial debt are profound. Graduates frequently face years of financial strain, which can delay important life milestones such as buying a home, starting a family, or saving for retirement.  The escalating cost of higher education remains the underlying issue. Tuition and fees have increased significantly over the past decades, outpacing wage growth and inflation. Simply forgiving loans without addressing these rising costs may offer temporary relief but fails to prevent future students from falling into similar debt traps. Instead, the federal government should consider prioritizing education funding reforms that aim to control tuition costs, expand grant programs, and increase support for community colleges and vocational training.  Broader loan forgiveness programs have their merits, such as potentially stimulating economic growth by increasing consumer spending power and reducing financial stress for borrowers. However, these benefits might be enhanced when combined with initiatives that involve other agencies, organizations, and NGOs dedicated to educational support and financial literacy. Collaborating across sectors can ensure more comprehensive, sustainable solutions.  In conclusion, while broadening student-loan forgiveness programs can provide immediate relief, the federal government should prioritize multifaceted approaches that address the root causes of education debt. By reforming funding systems, controlling costs, and engaging diverse stakeholders, it is possible to create a more equitable and economically sound framework for future generations.

outline_text: -Thesis: No, employers should not require workers to return to the office as it's nothing more than a capitalistic ploy for control that doesn't actually benefit the company or the employee.   -Main points:  *COVID, an ONGOING pandemic/work place changes *Disability rights/accommodation  *Effect on productivity *Better for environment (commuting); saves employees money (and employers with food, office space, etc.)  *Offers adults flexibility, better for mental health, better for family and personal life
human_draft_text: In March of 2020, our workplaces changed forever. Five years into an ongoing pandemic and many corporations and government officials are pushing to return to the norms of life before COVID. The reality, however, is that life will never return to a pre-2020 norm and that's actually for the best. In fact, the recent push by corporations for a partial (or full) return to office is nothing more than a capitalistic ploy for control over employees that doesn't actually materially benefit the company or the employee.   Remote work in recent years has moved from a fringe accommodation for many disabled people, into becoming the norm. This is undoubtedly a good thing. It's meant that employers get to save money on office space, food expenses, utilities, etc. It's meant that employees get to save time and money on commuting, and it's even proved beneficial for the environment that people aren't driving as much as they used to. Instead of spending hours in their cars stuck in traffic, wasting hundreds of dollars a month on gas, they're spending more time with their families and with their communities.   It's undeniable that remote work offers adults more flexibility. It allows them the freedom to balance their work life with their personal life like never before. It's overall better for their mental health, and for their private lives. Why would an employer care anything about the personal effects of remote work? Because a happy, healthy workforce is a productive workforce. Studies have shown that COVID actually increased many people's productivity as the distractions of office life were cut out and they were better able to focus on their job. Higher productivity, no doubt means higher profits for the company. A win-win.   Ultimately, a corporation needs to trust its workforce. Forcing people to return to office is a misguided attempt at unnecessary oversight. Trusting employees to do their job, and giving them the space, freedom, and flexibility to do it on their terms from the comfort of their home is a guaranteed way to ensure productivity, higher profits, and an overall better quality of life for all those involved in the company.

Those with the latest models may be perceived as more popular or wealthy, fostering resentment and division among students. Students may easily switch from constructive activities to non-academic distractions such as messaging friends or browsing unrelated content. Teachers and staff cannot constantly monitor every student's device, making enforcement impractical and ineffective.  Finally, the argument that smartphones are necessary in emergencies is not convincing. Schools have established protocols for handling urgent situations. outline_text: Most of us have heard of these old adages: "Life is unfair", and "Life is hard." As long as the outcome is guaranteed to be positive, or is at least very likely to be positive, then I don't see the harm in parents being given the right to genetically edit their unborn child to prevent diseases. Naturally, many parents and parents-to-be hope to shield their children from unnecessary suffering. One of the most profound hardships a person can face is being born with a debilitating disease or being predisposed to severe illnesses later in life. Given this reality, it is understandable why some would argue that parents should have the right to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent such diseases.  Advancements in genetic technology have opened the door to the possibility of identifying and correcting genetic defects before a child is even born. If the outcome of such interventions is guaranteed or at least highly likely to be positive—resulting in a healthy life free from hereditary diseases—then restricting parents from utilizing these technologies seems unnecessarily cruel. Preventing suffering where possible is a fundamental human value, and genetic editing offers the potential to alleviate or eliminate a wide range of conditions, such as cystic fibrosis, Huntington’s disease, or certain forms of cancer. Denying parents this option would mean consigning children to potentially preventable pain and hardship.  Some argue that genetic modifications could threaten natural human diversity, which is often seen as a valuable attribute of our species. However, the presence of disease is not a beneficial form of diversity; it is a source of pain rather than strength. Being born with a disease should not be romanticized as a way to teach life lessons or to appreciate human variety. Instead, why should we accept avoidable suffering on the grounds of preserving diversity? There are countless other aspects of human variation—culture, personality, talents—that contribute to the rich tapestry of humanity without causing harm. Allowing such interventions aligns with the natural parental desire to protect children from suffering and promotes healthier lives. Preserving natural human diversity is important, but it should not come at the cost of unnecessary pain and disease. Medical advancements exist to improve quality of life, and it would be both ethical and compassionate to embrace them.

outline_text: Bringing back extinct animals may cause damage to balance in current ecosystems. They could also bring back diseases that we have no knowledge of how to cure. If Jurassic Park has taught us anything, it's that these things should not be done lightly, they may cause severe safety risks! They would however be fascinating to study and could perhaps lead to scientific breakthroughs that would otherwise be obscured from us.
ai_draft_text: The idea of bringing back extinct species such as the woolly mammoth through genetic engineering has sparked significant debate. While the prospect of reviving these ancient creatures is fascinating and holds potential for scientific advancement, it is crucial to consider the possible consequences before crossing this natural boundary.  One major concern is the impact that reintroducing extinct animals could have on current ecosystems. Modern environments have evolved and adapted in the absence of these species, and their sudden reintroduction might disrupt the balance. New or reintroduced species could compete with existing wildlife for resources, potentially leading to unforeseen ecological problems. The delicate interplay among species is a result of millennia of evolution, and disturbing it risks cascading effects that are difficult to predict.  Furthermore, there is the danger of resurrecting unknown diseases. Extinct animals may carry pathogens that have long disappeared but could be harmful to contemporary species, including humans. Our lack of knowledge and preparedness to handle such diseases could result in public health crises. This risk underscores the precautionary principle, suggesting that we should avoid tampering with extinct species without fully understanding the potential ramifications.  Popular culture offers cautionary tales about the dangers of reviving extinct creatures. The movie Jurassic Park famously illustrated how genetic engineering, when rushed or mismanaged, can lead to severe safety risks and catastrophic outcomes. Although fictional, the narrative reflects real concerns about the ethical and practical challenges involved in de-extinction efforts. It reminds us that such scientific endeavors should not be undertaken lightly.  On the other hand, bringing extinct species back could provide invaluable opportunities for scientific study. Researchers could gain insights into evolutionary processes, genetics, and ancient ecosystems that are currently inaccessible. These breakthroughs might pave the way for advancements in medicine, conservation, and our understanding of life on Earth.  In conclusion, while the revival of extinct species like the woolly mammoth presents exciting possibilities, the potential ecological damage, health risks, and safety concerns suggest caution. Extinction has long been a natural boundary, and respecting it may ultimately be the wisest choice. However, with thoughtful regulation and thorough research, the scientific benefits of de-extinction could be responsibly explored.

This does not appear to be the case - employees who are more effective in an office environment will always have that option, those who work better without distraction may well find remote work more effective and to deprive workers of the choice suggests that the real reason has more to do with micromanaging bosses needing staff in the office in order to peer over their shoulders and scrutinize their every move - if they are working from home they can only be judged by their output and thus the role of a lot of middle managers could come under scrutiny. The benefits on the other hand are numerous. In the short term, reducing office capacity will result in either selling office space or cutting the rental bill, either way this will be a boost to cash flow. A sensible and permissive WFH policy that treats workers like mature adults instead of naughty schoolchildren will attract better candidates for new jobs and boost staff morale, offsetting any potential costs from having the offices at much less than 100% capacity. Anyone found to be "slacking off" will be found out quickly - perhaps once the dust has settled, the ones most under threat will be those annoying middle managers!

outline_text: I. Why public schools should ban smartphones during the school day     1. Potential for use in classrooms as cheating devices    2. Potential for constant distraction from learning, limiting concentration    3. Potential for use as bullying devices during school day  II. Why arguments for permitting them are wrong     1. Not necessary as learning devices because teachers will instruct children, and most classrooms also have computers     2. Not necessary for emergencies because adults at school will have phones in case of emergencies
ai_draft_text: Should Public Schools Ban Smartphones During the School Day?  The question of whether public schools should ban smartphones during the school day has sparked considerable debate. While some argue for limited use of these devices for learning and emergencies, a closer examination reveals that banning smartphones is a more prudent approach. Smartphones present several challenges in educational settings, including facilitating cheating, causing distractions, and enabling bullying, all of which undermine the school environment.  First, smartphones have the potential to be used as cheating devices in classrooms. With internet access and messaging applications, students can easily look up answers or communicate covertly during tests and assignments. This compromises academic integrity and makes it difficult for teachers to accurately assess students’ understanding. The presence of smartphones thus threatens the fairness and effectiveness of the educational process.  Second, smartphones act as constant distractions that limit students’ concentration and engagement in learning. Notifications, social media, games, and messaging tempt students to divert their attention away from lessons. This fragmented focus hinders the absorption of material and adversely affects academic performance. Even with intentions to use smartphones for educational purposes, the risk of distraction remains significant.  Third, smartphones can be instruments for bullying during the school day. Cyberbullying is a serious problem among young people, and allowing students to have access to their phones at school increases the chances of harmful messages, exclusion, or harassment occurring in real time. Keeping smartphones out of the classroom helps foster a safer and more respectful environment for all students.  Proponents of limited smartphone use often claim these devices are necessary learning tools or emergency communication devices. However, these arguments are flawed. Teachers are fully capable of delivering instruction without reliance on students’ smartphones, and most classrooms are equipped with computers or tablets designed specifically for educational use. Additionally, in emergencies, it is not students who need to communicate, but rather the adults in charge, who have access to phones and other reliable means of contacting emergency services or parents.  In conclusion, public schools should ban smartphones during the school day. Their potential for cheating, distraction, and bullying far outweighs any claimed educational or emergency benefits. By restricting smartphone use, schools can promote integrity, focus, and safety, thereby creating a better learning environment for all students.

I think the rules should be dictated by those factors, and 'blanket rules' that apply everywhere are easy to think about, but not practical in reality.  Some studies have shown that teams are more effective when working together in the same physical location, while other studies have demonstrated teams being more effective when working remotely. There is documented scientific evidence for both sides of the argument.  In my job as a software engineer, I find myself to be effective in a remote-focused but hybrid situation. I work from home for 4 days/week, and I got into the office for 1 day. I can communicate with my coworkers asynchronously online via email or Slack, or synchronously via audio/video conferencing. I find that balance suits me well.  However, we have different personality types on the team, and some people in our group prefer more direct in-person socializing, and they choose to be in the office more days per week. We have the flexibility to set a work schedule that prioritizes the needs of each individual employee.  There are many types of businesses where a virtual presence isn't feasible at all. For example, someone who is building robots might be able to do a good chunk of the work online, but they might have a stronger need for a centralized physical presence where they have access to the professional tools and equipment provided by the company.  The situation is highly dependent on the company, the type of work being performed, and the personalities of the people involved. Therefore I think it is kind of reductive to boil the topic down to 'should we do A or B', when the reality of the situation is much more nuanced.

Minor diseases that large amounts of the population are prone to, such as asthma and heart disease that is relatively well controlled, should not be edited out. There are additional questions that need to be answered though. Could editing genes to prevent these diseases lead to unknown or new issues, is there a risk that we could end up introducing new mutations that could create new diseases or problems for the baby? If we do end up with fewer rare diseases, are we really making the gene pool less diverse or are we merely preventing serious disease and suffering. There is a risk that parents may not just stop with disease prevention and we could end up crossing the line into full blown genetic modification. There is also a risk that banning this could lead to the whole thing going underground. This could introduce risks for everyone with unscrupulous doctors who may well not be qualified to do such gene editing attempting to do this behind closed doors which could lead to bigger issues in the future both for the baby and, in the worst case scenario, for future generations if a gene that edited out or changed causes issues for future generations. There is also the counter argument about whether editing children's genes to prevent disease would lead to a less diverse gene pool anyway. Are we not merely preventing human suffering?
final_text: This is a complex problem that has no simple answer. The first problem is what kind of diseases are we talking about? Suitable diseases for gene editing should be defined as those that are life-threatening, significantly reduce quality of life, or have no effective treatment options.  Minor diseases that large amounts of the population are prone to, such as asthma and heart disease that are generally well managed, should not be edited out. There are additional questions that need to be answered though. Could editing genes to prevent these diseases lead to unknown or new issues, is there a risk that we could end up introducing new mutations that could create new diseases or problems for the baby. If we do end up with fewer rare diseases, are we really making the gene pool less diverse or are we merely preventing serious disease and suffering. There is a risk that parents may not just stop with disease prevention and we could end up crossing the line into full-blown genetic modification. Bioethicists warn that without strict regulatory frameworks, gene editing could extend beyond disease prevention into non-therapeutic enhancements. There is also a risk that banning this could lead to the whole thing going underground. This could introduce risks for everyone with unscrupulous doctors who may well not be qualified to do such gene editing attempting to do this behind closed doors which could lead to bigger issues in the future both for the baby and, in the worst case scenario, for future generations if a gene that is edited out or changed causes issues for future generations. There is also the counter argument about whether gene editing to prevent disease reduces genetic diversity. Are we not merely preventing human suffering? Geneticists generally agree that preventing certain rare diseases is unlikely to significantly reduce overall genetic diversity in the human population.
