Introduction     student debt crisis     current debate and solutions     thesis statement: the federal government should pursue a balanced approach that combines targeted loan forgiveness and systemic reforms to address the root causes.  2. Loan forgiveness benefits such as immediate relief, reduced inequality                                 Drawbacks- cost, fairness concern  3. alternative approaches such as income based reforms, education cost reduction, financial literacy   4. Conclusion: balanced approach recommendation remains the best
human_draft_text: The student debt problem has become a major concern across the United States. Many students graduate with loans they struggle to pay back for years or even in decades. This has led to an important debate about how federal government should tackle this issue.   Some people believe the government should expand the student loan forgiveness programs. The approach would cancel debts for millions of student, and give them immediate relief from their financial burden.  Those who support this idea point that it would help them reduce the wealth gap between the different groups. They also argue that when formers students have more money to spend, the whole economy benefits. people can buy homes, start a business and contribute more to their communities when not pulled back by their student debts.   Others think the government should focus on different solutions. Those who worry about the high cost of large scale debt cancellation and question whether it treats all citizens fairly. The critics suggests that a loan forgiveness program would not entirely fix what caused the problem in the first place- the high cost of college education. They prefer solutions that address the root causes.   A balanced approach would combine elements from both sides. The government could offer targeted debt relief for specific groups such as public service workers or low income borrowers, and also  work on broad reforms to to make the education more affordable for future students. Better financial education about college costs and loans would help students make informed choices.   Indeed, the student debt crisis has no specific solution to fix it. Its demands a highly thoughtful action that helps current borrowers without creating new problems. A hybrid approach that offer immediate relief and integrates long term reforms can address the modern debt crisis. The goals is to build a realistic system for a better tomorrow.
final_text: The student debt problem has become a major concern across the United States. Many students graduate with loans they struggle to pay back for years or even decades. This has led to an important debate about how the federal government should tackle this issue.   Some people believe the government should expand the student loan forgiveness programs. The approach would cancel debts for millions of student, and give them immediate relief from their financial burden.  Those who support this idea point out that it would help them reduce the wealth gap between the different groups. Loan forgiveness can reduce the wealth gap by enabling borrowers from disadvantaged backgrounds to invest in assets like homes and retirement funds that build long-term wealth. They also argue that when former students have more money to spend, the whole economy benefits. people can buy homes, start a business and contribute more to their communities when not pulled back by their student debts.   Others think the government should focus on different solutions. Those who worry about the high cost of large scale debt cancellation also question whether it treats all citizens fairly. The critics suggests that a loan forgiveness program would not entirely fix what caused the problem in the first place- the high cost of college education. They prefer solutions that address the root causes.   A balanced approach would combine elements from both sides. The government could offer targeted debt relief for specific groups such as public service workers or low income borrowers, and also  work on broad reforms to make education more affordable for future students. Better financial education about college costs and loans would help students make informed choices.   Indeed, the student debt crisis has no specific solution to fix it. It demands highly thoughtful actions that help current borrowers without creating new problems. A hybrid approach that offer immediate relief and integrates long term reforms can address the modern debt crisis. For example, the government could first forgive debts for low-income graduates while simultaneously implementing tuition caps and increasing funding for community colleges to prevent future debt accumulation. The goals is to build a realistic system for a better tomorrow.

Annecdotally, the ages when students have smartphones is getting younger as parents want to be in contact with their kids in case of emergencies. Also, youths now grow up with this technology and is the primary way they communicate with their peers or others. This has been a crutch and it's debated if this helps or hurts their learning in a school setting. One argument for its benefit is that it can be used as part of the active learning process. For example, it can be used as a tool for answer questions that the teacher poses. This active learning is known to be a good strategy for learning. On the other hand there are a few arguments againts the use of smartphones despite the aforementioned benefits. It is clear that having a smartphone is a temptation when it's available to students to be distracted, or worse, for cheating. When students have easy access to look things up, it makes the learning process less effective - critical thinking is not developed as efficiently and students can fall behind. At the same time, students that use smartphones during class (even when not allowed) can be a distraction to the teaching, and also to other students. This is similar to issues of students using other devices in class, like laptops or related devices with screens. Overall, despite the limited benefits that smartphones might have to educaiton, the negatives outweight that. A study that evaluates safety in contexts of students having or not a smartphone would help to clarify this.
final_text: With the ubiquity of smartphones in society, there is an increasing proportion of students that have a smartphone. Annecdotally, the ages when students have smartphones are getting younger as parents want to be in contact with their kids in case of emergencies. Also, youths now grow up with this technology and are the primary way they communicate with their peers or others. This has been a crutch and it's debated if this helps or hurts their learning in a school setting. One argument for its benefit is that it can be used as part of the active learning process. For example, smartphones enable students to participate in live polls or access educational apps that reinforce lesson content in real-time, which has been shown to enhance engagement and retention. For example, it can be used as a tool to answer questions that the teacher poses during class in interactive quizzes or research activities. This active learning is known to be a good strategy for learning. Also, a smarphone allows students to look up content easily if needed for activities that require it. On the other hand there are a few arguments against the use of smartphones despite the aforementioned benefits. It is clear that having a smartphone is a temptation when it's available to students to be distracted, or worse, for cheating. When students have easy access to look things up, it makes the learning process less effective - critical thinking is not developed as efficiently and students can fall behind. Research indicates that in classrooms allowing smartphones, approximately 30% of students admit to using them to cheat, while 40% report being distracted by notifications during lessons. At the same time, students that use smartphones during class (even when not allowed) can be a distraction to the teaching, and also to other students. This is similar to issues of students using other devices in class, like laptops or related devices with screens. Overall, despite the limited benefits that smartphones might have to educaiton, the negatives outweight that. While smartphones can offer valuable learning tools, their drawbacks such as distraction and reduced critical thinking skills often outweigh these benefits in traditional classroom settings. However, with proper guidelines and technology integration, their potential can be better harnessed. In regards to safety, even though it might feel more safe if a student has a smartphone, it's unclear if the data supports this. A study that evaluates safety in contexts of students having or not a smartphone would help to clarify this. human_draft_text: School districts across the nation are enacting cell phone bans during the school day.  Policies vary by district, but the trend is to ban phone use in class at the very least.  These new policies and practices are driven by concern for student learning and mental health.  Cell phones distract students from the classroom and each other; provide a method for cheating, contribute to bullying through social media apps, and keep students in sometimes constant contact with helicopter parents.  All of this leads to students with mental health issues like depression and anxiety that are linked both to cell phone use, and to the lack of social skills for interacting with peers in person. Parents, administrators, and other adults concerned with student academic performance and mental health have put their foot down and put cell phone bans in place.  GenXers like me remember the old days when, if our parents needed to reach us during the school day, or we needed to talk with them, we worked through the school office.  We could use the phone to call our parent.  They could call the office and leave a message for us, resulting in us getting a note in class.  Or we might be called to the office over the intercom to take an important call.  Those methods still work and can be reimplemented today.    But what will my student do when there's a mass shooting, they are hiding in the bathroom, and they want to tell me they love me one more time before they die?  That is the scenario that parents and students use to argue against a cell-phone ban.  It's tragic that this prospect needs to be considered.  It's a rare occurrence, but it's very much on everyone's mind.  Our daily practices and policies should be guided by our daily needs, and the primary focus of school: educating students.  That will best be done when we put students needs -- both educational, social, and mental health -- in the foreground.  Mass shooting happen, but we can't let that rare prospect dictate routine classroom needs.  Will cell phone bans solve everthing?  Stay tuned.  The experiment is in progress in classrooms across the country.

outline_text: Intro: * What is genetic modification * Why is it controversial  Evidence: * Pros of genetic modification   - Prevent deadly diseases given to innocent children   - Improve overall health of society   - Reduce net drag on societal welfare systems * Cons of genetic modification   - Reduce natural diversity   - Slippery slope to non-health-related genetic modifications   - not "natural"  Argument: - Weigh pros and cons - Come down on a side - Rationalize decision  Conclusion: - Summarize argument - Repeat decision
human_draft_text: As modern technology advances, it is becoming apparent that parents will soon be able to modify the genes of their unborn children. This is an extremely controversial topic with many proponents on both sides of the argument. The concept of interfering with nature is off-putting to many, though others are animated by the potential held within. Is this a technology we should allow?  People for genetic modification of unborn children argue that this technology could potentially save millions of lives. Using genetic modification, we could virtually eradicate a number of various diseases, genetic mutations, and birth abnormalities. Not only would this save many innocent children, but it would improve the overall health of society in the process, leading to a more robust citizenry. In addition, it would reduce the overall financial and social burden on society and the economy due to reduced medical costs and reduced emotional and mental resources.  On the other hand, people again genetic modification argue that it is a slippery slope. Not only are we messing with the natural world, but we cannot know the unforeseen consequences, nor can we ever know. It is possible that modifying the genes to prevent a disease could cause an entirely new disease. Other argue that it will justify non-medical gene intervention, such as choosing eye color, hair color, and even physique and talent, leading to designer babies that only the very wealthy can afford. This could lead to a gate-kept world where the rich get richer and the poor get poorer.  It is a delicate balance of pros and cons. The author of this essay believes the prospect of curing millions of innocent children from debilitating, often deadly diseases far outweighs any potential cost. We can regulate the practice to ensure genetic modification is only available for medical purposes, putting strict punishment on those who use it for aesthetic purpose or to derive social benefits. In the end, saving lives is more important than staying in line with nature or worrying about vague what-if scenarios.
final_text: As modern technology advances, it is becoming apparent that parents will soon be able to modify the genes of their unborn children. This is an extremely controversial topic with many proponents on both sides of the argument. The concept of interfering with nature is off-putting to many, though others are animated by the potential held within. Is this a technology we should allow?  People for genetic modification of unborn children argue that this technology could potentially save millions of lives. Using genetic modification, we could virtually eradicate a number of various diseases, genetic mutations, and birth abnormalities. Not only would this save many innocent children, but it would improve the overall health of society in the process, leading to a more robust citizenry. In addition, it would reduce the financial and social burden on society due to reduced medical costs and reduced emotional and mental resources.  On the other hand, people against genetic modification argue that it is a slippery slope. Not only are we messing with the natural world, but we cannot know the unforeseen consequences, nor will we ever know. It is possible that modifying the genes to prevent a disease could cause an entirely new disease. For example, studies on CRISPR gene editing have revealed potential off-target mutations that could lead to unforeseen health issues, highlighting the need for caution. Others argue that it will justify non-medical gene intervention, such as choosing eye color, hair color, and even physique and talent, leading to designer babies that only the very wealthy can afford. To counteract the slippery slope, strict legal frameworks and ethical guidelines can delineate acceptable uses, as seen in current gene therapy regulations. This could lead to a gate-kept world where the rich get richer and the poor get poorer.  It is a delicate balance of pros and cons. The author of this essay believes the prospect of curing millions of innocent children from debilitating, often deadly diseases far outweighs any potential cost. We can regulate the practice to ensure genetic modification is only available for medical purposes, putting strict punishment on those who use it for aesthetic purposes or to derive social benefits. While regulation is essential, it must include robust enforcement mechanisms such as international ethical committees and transparent oversight to prevent misuse effectively. For instance, international organizations like the WHO could establish binding ethical codes and monitoring systems similar to those used for vaccine approval to enforce regulations globally. In the end, saving lives is more important than staying in line with nature or worrying about uncertain potential risks. Ethical concerns and potential long-term risks must be carefully evaluated, similar to how other medical advances like vaccines faced initial uncertainty but proved beneficial with regulation.

The distraction of a phone during learning time has been proven to take away from what is being presented during learning for young people. Studies by organizations like the Pew Research Center show that students using smartphones in class score lower on tests by an average of 10%. For example, a 2019 Pew Research Center study involving 1,000 high school students found that those who used smartphones during lessons scored on average 10% lower in standardized tests compared to peers who did not. final_text: Should Public schools ban smartphones during the school day or permit limited use for learning and emergencies?  Smartphones have become part of everyday life and schools have not been spared. The question is whether students should be allowed to use them during the school day. Some argue that schools should ban them due to the distractions. I don't believe in that, a ban is too much. Instead public schools should allow limited use of smartphones for learning and emergencies while establishing new rules to prevent misuse. A teacher might want to use a quiz app to understand a particular concept or a teacher might want students to look up primary sources online. Taking phones or banning them takes away these opportunities and ignores that technology is part of modern education.  Secondly smartphones are important for safety and communication. In the case of a medical concern or a security one, being able to quickly reach emergency services or parents matters. Guardians may also feel comfortable knowing they can contact their children just in case something happens. Having that connection adds a security comfort that a ban wouldn't have.  The concern for distractions is real, but this is where schools can step in with clear rules like phones should be on silent during class, used only in permitted areas and break times, with teacher permission in class, and during emergencies. Also, students should not use social media during the school day. These rules will help maintain focus and support students in today’s technology-driven world.  Banning smartphones is unrealistic and unproductive. Allowing limited use teaches students how to handle technology responsibly, supports learning and ensures safety. Guiding students is the wise decision to make rather than banning smartphones in public schools.

final_text: It has always been the aim of humans to strive for better, for perfection. But humans, by our very nature, are imperfect. We succumb to cancers, mental health issues, and diseases, but modern medicine has advanced many cures and prevention methods. We are still susceptible to so much. What if we could find a way to cure any genetic disease? Scientists have discovered ways to genetically edit their unborn children to prevent genetic mutations which cause disease. Sounds great until you dig deeper and uncover ethical and social issues. Examples of ethical concerns include the potential for exacerbating social inequalities, issues around informed consent, and the risk of eugenics-like practices.  Those in favour mention that this is just the next stage of human evolution. While plants and fruits have been genetically modified for centuries, humans possess greater biological complexity and ethical considerations, requiring careful regulation beyond simple evolutionary steps. We have improved plants and fruits through genetic modifications for millennia; why not apply this to humans next? If we can eliminate diseases such as cancers, this can only be a good thing. The secondary benefits are also said to be great. There will be less illness, fewer sick days, more economic productivity. Our quality of life will improve significantly.  Those against the idea might argue that we are playing God and we are meddling with nature. Many religious groups have historically been against such issues. It would probably be very expensive and only wealthy families would be able to afford it thus widening the societal gaps between rich and poor. Governments could implement subsidies or enforce universal healthcare coverage for genetic therapies to prevent socioeconomic disparities in access. For example, cutting-edge treatments like IVF and gene therapies have initially been accessible only to affluent groups, deepening health inequality. Many biologists say we would have a loss of biodiversity, with only a relatively small number of traits being chosen. The slippery slope here is that we do not stop with diseases, but then begin to choose physical characteristics also. Bioethicists warn that initial acceptance of genetic disease prevention could lead to designer babies, as seen in debates on cosmetic genetic enhancements. We have also seen that small changes to complex biological systems can have drastic consequences, for example with the climate. For example, off-target gene edits can cause unintended mutations, potentially resulting in new diseases or harmful traits. Who knows what unforeseen consequences this might cause.  A compromise focusing on targeted benefits would be sensible and this technology is likely to continue. Therefore, while genetic editing holds significant promise to eliminate disease, strict ethical frameworks and equitable access must be established to prevent misuse and social disparity.

outline_text: In this essay I will demonstrate that parents should be empowered to safely give birth to children free of serious genetic defects and congenital disease. I will argue that eradicating serious congenital disease and genetic defects would not run the risk of upsetting natural human diversity, as severe genetic defects and congenital disease can be incompatible with life or severely life-limiting.

As such it is natural to feel concerned that allowing parents the right to genetically edit embryos could lead to a moral crisis, and thinning the pool of natural human diversity.   Whilst such concerns are understandable, and I would not argue for unfettered access to genetic modification, I feel that it is a bit of a straw man argument when in the pursuit of avoiding serious genetic defects and congenital disease. Many serious genetic defects can result in conditions that are incompatible with life, or are life-limiting - for example anencephaly and certain trisomies. These children are unlikely to be born, or survive infancy / childhood and thus would not go on to contribute to the genetic pool of natural human diversity in any event.  In addition to this, such serious congenital disease and genetic defects can result in immense emotional and financial burdens, both to the parents and immediate family, and to the healthcare system respectively. I was rendered completely unable to enjoy my successful pregnancy and was riddled with anxiety when my ultimately healthy baby was born. Whilst such concerns are understandable, and I would not argue for unfettered access to genetic modification, I feel that it is a bit of a straw man argument when it comes to the pursuit of avoiding serious genetic defects and congenital disease. Many serious genetic defects can result in conditions that are incompatible with life or are life-limiting; for example, anencephaly and certain trisomies. These children are unlikely to be born or survive infancy/childhood and thus would not go on to contribute to the genetic pool of natural human diversity in any event.  In addition to this, such serious congenital disease and genetic defects can result in immense emotional and financial burdens, both to the parents and immediate family, and to the healthcare system respectively. As a parent myself who has had to make very difficult decisions after having a pregnancy ending with a termination for medical reasons due to anencephaly, and a subsequent successful but fraught pregnancy with concerns of trisomies (Edwards/Patau) requiring chorionic villus sampling, I can attest that these experiences were deeply distressing and had a lasting impact. Studies indicate that families affected by severe genetic conditions experience significantly higher rates of psychological distress and financial hardship compared to the general population. I was rendered completely unable to enjoy my successful pregnancy and was riddled with anxiety when my ultimately healthy baby was born.   There are families with autosomal genetic disease in a far more precarious position than we were, I know, and their heartbreak and experiences bear weight in this discussion.   In conclusion, I believe that ultimately allowing parents to genetically edit embryos bearing genetic defects indicative of serious, congenital disease that is either incompatible with life or severely life-limiting is beneficial for society and reflects a greater good.

outline_text: Implementing structured smartphone policies balances educational benefits with minimizing disruptions.  - Introduce debate on smartphone use in schools and need for balanced policies - Smartphones enhance learning with educational apps and quick information access - Unrestricted use causes distractions, reduces focus, and impacts social interaction - Limited use policies allow emergency contact while maintaining classroom discipline - Conclude that structured smartphone rules maximize benefits and minimize disruptions
human_draft_text: It's clear that smartphone use has sapped entire generations of their attention spans, attention to detail, and depth of thought. There's no clearer evidence of that than in Generations Z and Alpha, who largely grew up with smartphones from childhood onward, and have (even accounting for the disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic) had some of the most substantial proficiency dips in the history of American public education. It's obvious, at this point, that something must be done: Schools need to ban general use of smartphones, providing only a limited use case in the event of emergencies, and potentially as a carefully administered supplement to in-class learning.  An outright ban would be foolhardy, of course, since many (if not most) students would move heaven and earth to circumvent that ban. Certainly, the zero-tolerance policies of the 2000s (when cell phones were, ironically, only a fraction as distracting) mostly just taught students when and where to hide their phones from teachers and staff. But a general restriction on phone use during class hours would be an excellent start; banning phone use at lunch, or in the halls between classes, is optional but recommended.  While there are some genuinely useful applications for smartphone use in the classroom (e.g., using mobile apps to answer quizzes) they are, of course, limited. Generally speaking, the chance for distraction is too great to allow unrestricted phone access during classroom hours, except in cases of confirmed emergencies.  Structuring smartphone rules to allow for flexibility in the classroom at teachers' discretion, and in emergency cases, while also broadly banning phone use for the general student body would minimize disruptions, likely improve attention spans, and potentially limit the scope of cyberbullying among students.  Implementing structured smartphone policies balances educational benefits with minimizing disruptions.  - Introduce debate on smartphone use in schools and need for balanced policies
final_text: It's clear that smartphone use has sapped entire generations of their attention spans, attention to detail, and depth of thought. There's no clearer evidence of that than in Generations Z and Alpha, who largely grew up with smartphones from childhood onward, and have (even prior to the disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic) had some of the most substantial proficiency dips in the history of American public education. It's obvious, at this point, that something must be done: Schools need to ban general use of smartphones, allowing only limited use in the event of emergencies, and potentially as a carefully administered supplement to in-class learning.  An outright ban would be foolhardy, of course, since many (if not most) students would move heaven and earth to circumvent that ban. Certainly, the zero-tolerance policies of the 2000s—when cell phones were, ironically, only a fraction as distracting—mostly just taught students when and where to hide their phones from teachers and staff. But a general restriction on phone use during class hours would be an excellent start; banning phone use at lunch, or in the halls between classes, is optional but recommended.  While there are some genuinely useful applications for smartphone use in the classroom (e.g., using mobile apps to answer quizzes) they are, of course, limited, and most of those applications could also be run on school-provided laptops or Chromebooks. The same goes for students' ability to quickly look up information on the Internet. Generally speaking, the chance for distraction is too great to allow unrestricted phone access during classroom hours, except in cases of confirmed emergencies, or in specific instances where phones are approved for academic use by individual teachers.  Structuring smartphone rules to allow for flexibility in the classroom at teachers' discretion, and in emergency cases, while also broadly banning phone use for the general student body would minimize disruptions, likely improve attention spans, enable more genuine peer-to-peer in-person interaction, and potentially limit the incidence of cyberbullying among students. Those undeniably positive outcomes outweigh whatever complaints students might have in the process.

While extinction may seem like a finality, advances in genetic engineering have called that into question. Due to modern science, it may be possible to genetically reproduce extinct species from many time periods. This unique and marvelous idea could revive lost ecosystems and the balance of bio diversity. These advances in science can drive innovation responsibly, in a way that helps the entire planet. We can bring back species thought lost in time and bring about a wonderful new age of discovery and re-discovery of nature. Many people will object, saying this is playing God with our scientific knowledge. They would wonder if we might cause more damage than good things by bringing back extinct species. There may be ethical and environmental concerns, but these can be managed with responsible regulation. Governments can work with scientists to manage this properly and make sure we do not cause a catastrophic situation. To the religious objections, it must be said that many religious people believe in Heaven on earth, and helping to revive lost species may be a first step towards bringing back all the people and animals that have been lost to time. We can make the world a better place by reviving these lost creatures of the past.

Universities should charge less and engage more in the process of matching education with skills in the workforce.

This leaves borrowers with insurmountable debt that oftentimes does not materialize into a sustainable career. Instead, the government should focus on making education more affordable at every level.    Student loan forgiveness is broadly unfair. Many borrowers with the largest debt have higher degrees and enjoy greater income potential. In this case, the loan forgiveness is tantamount to a wealth subsidy. Taxpayer money should not be used to relieve debt for those who can afford to repay their debt. Conversely, bachelor-level degrees incur less debt but often have far less income potential. Some degrees have almost no income potential, yet students pursue these degrees with little education in career awareness. outline_text: The idea of reviving an extinct species has always been a tempting one. There is some merit in this, if it pertains to species that were wiped out by human intervention in the last 100 years. I don't consider that an arbitrary number, and it is also why I don't think otherwise extinct species should be "brought back".  With the genetic tools currently available and enough viable physical matter, it would be possible to reconstruct a facsimile of an extinct species, such as the woolly mammoth. However, that is all it would be--a facsimile. The idea is to attempt to modify the DNA of an existing species that is related to the mammoth to some degree, such as an elephant. The end result might look something like a woolly mammoth and even share some DNA with a woolly mammoth, but in reality it would just be a hairier elephant.   For the sake of argument, let us assume it would be possible to perfectly clone an animal from the source material without having to modify the genetics of an existing species. I still think this would be a bad idea, and that brings us back to my comment about the last 100 years. The ecological context of the mammoth no longer exists. They would not be able to be released into the wild because the wild that remains is not one that can effectively support a woolly mammoth. If it could, there would probably still be woolly mammoths, assuming humans hadn't wiped them out by now, which is a distinct possibility. The only point of cloning such a creature is to have it as a curiosity, to do it for the sake of novelty. It has nothing to do with the well-being of the creature.   Yet, why would I support the idea of using genetic engineering to bring back a more recently extinct species? Because its habitat might still exist. There would be a space for those animals to return to the wild. It's a legitimate way to make use of that kind of technology.
human_draft_text: An extinct species is extinct for a reason. Sometimes this is due to a catastrophic event, or a milder yet inexorable change in habitat. These changes can occur with or without the intervention of humans. The idea of reviving an extinct species can be an exciting one, but in general I don't think it should be done, with the exception of recently extinct animals that were wiped out because of human interference.   The primary reason against the idea is that the resultant animal will only ever be a reconstructed facsimile of the extinct species. With long dead species, the best that can be done with the current technology is to tamper with the DNA of a closely related animal; with the woolly mammoth, that would be an elephant. The end result might look like a woolly mammoth but in reality it would simply be a hairier than average elephant.   For the sake of argument, let us assume it would be possible to perfectly clone an animal from the source material without having to modify the genetics of an existing species. The primary issue with this is that this species no longer has an appropriate habitat; it cannot be released into the wild. Its only reason for being is for the novelty of seeing a long-dead species, for doing it simply because it can be done. This does not take into account the well-being of the "revived" species at all. If the environment could still support the woolly mammoth, then the woolly mammoth probably would not have gone extinct when it did.  However, I would support the idea of using these genetic tools to bring back a more recently extinct species, one that was wiped out in the last 100 years or so. It is possible that the habitats for these species might still exist as they did. That would give them a place to return to the wild without unbalancing the ecology of that environment. This kind of technology should not be wasted on curiosities just to sate the ego of the people who are doing it to prove that they can. It should be used to make up for the massive amount of destruction caused by human civilization that has caused the extinction of so many species within living memory.

outline_text: -Introduction    -"Picture this" sort of nightmare attention grabber about woolly mammoths  -What does it mean to say there is a 'natural boundary'    -Problematize the word 'natural'  -The problem with bringing back woolly mammoths is not about its 'naturalness' but its ethical implications     -Where would they live? How would they disrupt local ecosystems? What would the quality of life be for them and for the animals in those ecosystems?  -Conclusion
human_draft_text: The year is 2319. The last remaining human inhabitants of the land formerly known as North America have just left to their new home with the rest of the human population. The mammoths now have the space to themselves. We knew we shouldn't have brought them back.   This is the sort of thing that the minds of many will go to when they think of the prospect of genetically engineering woolly mammoths back into existence. They imagine this is what will happen if we cross some natural boundary and that we will be punished for playing God by consequences unforeseen.   What does it mean to say that extinction is a 'natural boundary' that shouldn't be crossed? While I ultimately argue that we should not bring woolly mammoths back into existence on an ethical basis, I have no qualms with genetic engineering or whether or not things are 'natural.'   The most obvious way to rebuke any notion of naturalness is to remind ourselves that in one breath we can say that nature is red in tooth and claw, a competitive wasteland of the struggle to survive. In the next breath, we can just as easily toss about metaphors of nature as harmonious and balanced. Our very conception of what is natural is actually just historically and culturally conditioned. We just so happen to be living during an era in which naturalness is seen as a virtue, as having some intrinsic value that we should aspire to. We want our food, medicine, and clothing all natural. However, if we press on this even just a little bit, the very meaning of the word slips through our fingers.  This is all to say that I have no issue with the unnaturalness of genetically engineering woolly mammoths back into existence. I do, however, take issue with the sentient experience of the woolly mammoths we would be bringing into the world and the other sentient creatures, human and otherwise, that would be impacted. I do not believe there is a world in which they could live fulfilling lives free from pain on an ever-warming planet.

final_text: Since the COVID-19 pandemic, one of the main topics within the boardroom and the houses of parliament has been, "Should employees continue to work from home or should they be called into the office, working in a hybrid situation?"  There are so many topics that this situation addresses; it's an argument that does not seem to get settled.  After interviewing 30 candidates who have worked both hybrid and fully remote, we found that while the interviewed candidates provide valuable insights, the relatively small sample size may limit the generalizability of findings to the wider workforce. Larger-scale studies could provide more representative data. After carefully considering both pros and cons, we noticed that the same issues and benefits came up with each individual.    The candidates interviewed represented diverse industries, age groups, and regions to provide a balanced perspective on remote work experiences.  We also spoke to 30 managing directors from large enterprises and it seems they, too, struggle with a final choice.  Here are some of the topics brought up in the interviews:-  Working From Home Candidates Pros - No childcare fees Able to collect children from school, this gives a better relationship with the school and teachers. A better relationship at home with their child,  Saving on fuel and sustainability by reducing the carbon footprint. For example, eliminating daily commuting for a typical employee saves an average of 1,500 kg of CO2 emissions annually, contributing to corporate sustainability goals. Studies indicate that remote work can reduce individual carbon emissions by up to 30% due to decreased commuting.

final_text: The idea of reviving extinct species like the woolly mammoth has facinated the public and scientists alike for millenia. Thanks to rapid advances in Genetic capabilities, this is now closer to reality than fiction- and is something researchers are actively looking into. Yet, the question remains, should we do it? Is this a line we can afford to cross?   On the surface, the idea seems a compelling one, bringing back mamoths for one, could be potentially positive for the eco-system. Some argue they could even assist bring back grasslands to the artic. This could have massive climate change outcomes. Reviving some species could also lead to breakthroughs in genetic engineering, with spillover benefits in areas such as medicine and agriculture. There is also the alure beyond science, the curiosity of the masses and the hope that with such achievements, then we can surely fix the damage we've caused to the planet.   However, the case against de-extinction is equally strong- if not stronger. Ethical questions arise immidiately. Would the resurected animals enjoy the same quality of life as they had in their prehistoric eras? Who decides if, where and when the species are brought back? Equally important are the resources that would be used. Is this the best use of these resources?   In weighing both sides, I tend to proceed with caution. The technical aspect of bringing them back is without a doubt impressive. But capability and responsibility are two different things. Who would shoulder these responsibilities? Our governments? I believe that instead of focusing on reversing extinction, we should prioritize preserving, restoring and protecting the flaura and fauna that still sorrounds us today. I believe extinction should only serve to remind us of what we have lost and motivate us to act to prevent further loss- NOT tempt us into trying to play God with what we've lost.

human_draft_text: I believe that the federal government should not really go after broadening student-loan forgiveness because it does not actually fix the issue of the student loan crisis here in the United States. The colleges every single year over many decades keep increasing the price of tuition and other fees that have made affording college impossible. College is not affordable and no longer accessible for all. They have made college so expensive that taking out large loans for education is now the norm and now standard. They may say oh its okay because you can take out loans but it is not fixing the issue. It is a bandaid and making this worse. We are letting young people go straigt into college and take thousands if not hundreds of thousands of dollar out in loans with no promise of jobs. The degrees are now being eroded by AI and the workforce right now is making it hard for new grads to get into entry level jobs.   Degrees are not keeping up with the times and they are not getting people truly ready for the workforce at all. Degrees are costing more than peoples yearly salary's and that to me in insane. Where is the justification in that, that they can charge that. I have a cousin who is almost two-hundred thousand in debt. That is more than a mortgage and she can't even get a job in her degree field. I know countless others who went into a lot of debt for their degree. Maybe down the road the degree will be worth it but right now it isn't. The government needs to step in and fix the underlying issues of the college degree and the costs of it. There are many paths the government can take to do so. They need to priotitize that not just broadening student loan forgivness.
